TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is the Minister aware of the continuing progress being made by the South Australian Government in the establishment of a uranium enrichment industry in South Australia? Is the Commonwealth prepared to contribute its expertise in the preparation of a form of agreement suitable to become an Indenture Bill in due course? What would be the benefits to South Australia in the establishment of a uranium enrichment plant in South Australia? Could it be integrated with development of the Roxby Downs mineral deposit? Would there be any dangers to health in the operation of such a plant?
—Yes, there would be a lot.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the first interjection should come from a Labor senator opposing the idea of a very significant potential industry which would employ many hundreds of people--
—If you put it out--

—And some thousands of people in its building. It is worth understanding that the interjection continues. Time after time after time, the Australian Labor Party in this chamber is opposing good industries. For example, there is opposition to mining areas of South Australia including Roxby Downs and now uranium enrichment is opposed. I am aware of the keen interest of South Australia, and indeed, I think, of Queensland, in securing such an industry. I want to make it perfectly clear that that industry, which functions in a number of countries, is regarded, in relation to health, as a very safe industry. It is seen as one which presents no more threats to health than any chemical industry; it is not in itself a radioactive industry; and in fact uranium hexafluoride has a lower radiation than yellowcake and indeed lower than the ore itself in the ground. So, one must stop the kind of scare tactics that the Labor Party is constantly putting up. I repeat: A uranium enrichment industry, functioning as it does in a number of countries, has high health standards, has offered no threats at all to health, and is a chemical industry which--
—What is the commencement date-the year 2000?

—Ah, we are now talking about the commencement date. This is the Labor Party again knocking and knocking. A uranium enrichment industry has two characteristics. The first is conversion, whereby the yellowcake is converted under particular temperature by gas fluorine into uranium hexafluoride, a white powder. It is then spun in centrifuges so that the differing atomic weights of U235 and U238 are separated, so that the approximately 0.7 per cent of yellowcake is enriched to about 3.7 per cent. Whilst I am mentioning this matter, I give the lie to any thought that such an industry could be a weapons industry. It could not, in any way.

ANSWER.PARA: The industry would have enormous benefits for the particular State. I am told that it would employ some several thousand people to construct the plant, with at least 600 to 800 people permanently engaged directly, quite apart from the indirect benefits of all the ancillary industries. It could be integrated, and of course would be if it were in South Australia, with Roxby Downs or Honeymoon because those metal minings depend upon not only mining any one metal but also extracting copper, gold and uranium, as a balance, to earn a profit in a world which is cost conscious at this moment. So it would in fact be a significant thing in the integration of an industry.

I can only commend the Tonkin Government for its striving to get industries. I repeat: What South Australia has been suffering from is those 10 or 12 years or so of Labor State government when industries were repelled from the area. Now, of course, there is excitement that there will be industries coming to the State , with of course the foreshadowing of a liquids pipeline coming from the Cooper Basin bringing another major industry to South Australia.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that child care bodies funded by the Commonwealth Government are required to cater for disadvantaged families but that funding from the Commonwealth is insufficient to make up the shortfall caused by this special provision? Is it a fact that a majority of the 165 community child care bodies in Victoria funded by the Commonwealth Government will show a financial deficit in their operations by December this year? Will the Government give an undertaking that in its review of child care funding arrangements it will provide for additional funding for occasional child care facilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a rather odd three-part question because the parts do not relate in any way to each other. However, I will try to pick up the disparate points raised. It has been a requirement of the Commonwealth since, I think, 1976 that Commonwealth funded child care facilities should give priority of access to certain high need groups. The Prime Minister and the then Minister for Social Security both made statements in regard to this area, indicating that people such as sole parents, new migrants and others with a particular need for child care should be given priority of access. In addition, the Child Care Act provided for additional subsidy to be available for those having priority of access and there was also a provision for assistance to be given in cases of high economic need. One of the difficulties in the administration of the program is picked up by the second part of the honourable senator's question. The amount of the additional subsidies was stipulated by the Child Care Act and it is a fact that sometimes it was not possible for organisations to provide an adequate subsidy to admit those on very low incomes. I am sorry that the honourable senator has not bothered to read the material issued by me at the time of the Budget, which made it clear that we would be introducing a new form of subsidy, a special economic needs subsidy, which would give the child care centres much greater flexibility in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: I should mention to the Senate that we will, of necessity, be feeling our way because we do not have sufficient statistical material on the incomes of those using child care centres to be able to say precisely what levels of subsidy will be required, but already users have been circularised and advised that as from 1 January they will receive quarterly in advance a subsidy at the rate of, I think , $10 per week per effective full time child in each institution. This will enable organisations to start giving additional subsidy to economically needy cases. That will be monitored by the Department of Social Security in conjunction with the organisations and the amount of subsidy paid will be adjusted according to need. It would be envisaged that some child care centres catering for a substantial number of clients not in economic need would need less subsidy than others catering for people with greater economic need. The change in funding procedures, which will not take effect until 1 January, will not affect any deficits currently being experienced by centres but it should significantly increase the flexibility of centres in dealing with economically needy cases after 1 January. I regard that as a very important change in our approach to the funding of Commonwealth subsidised child care centres.

In respect of the third part of the question, which related to occasional care, I must say that I have considerable sympathy for the point made by Senator Robert Ray. In fact, until recently the established priority of my Department has been to provide full day care in priority to other forms of day care. That has been in accordance with the general professional advice available in this area. My own contact with users, particularly in suburban areas and not least in the western suburbs of Sydney, has convinced me that there is probably a high social need for occasional care in many of those areas and I would see it getting a rather higher priority in allocations than perhaps it has received over recent years. That is a matter which reflects my own experience of having contact with people seeking an extension of our activity in child care and I do think that for a very substantial number of mothers the occasional access to child care facilities can be of very real value and importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Although the provision of funding from 1 January may well ensure that no further deficits will be incurred , can the Minister suggest how any of those child care bodies are going to remove their existing deficits?

—As has been pointed out in the question, many hundreds of child care organisations are receiving subsidy from the Commonwealth. The extent of the subsidy is known to those organisations. It is their individual responsibility to budget to fit within the subsidies available. Additional economic need subsidies are available to organisations and some may be able to get assistance in that way. But in general it is the responsibility of the organisations concerned to budget within the confines of available assistance.

I will therefore ask Mr Macphee to examine the question asked by Senator Chipp and to consult with the Acting Attorney-General to enable a sensible response to be given. On the introduction to the question, I observe that there is nothing in the law, of course, which puts a foreign owned subsidiary in any position of advantage when compared with any Australian company or employer. From that point of view, I do not think the fact that International Harvester Australia Ltd is a foreign company is particularly relevant. I do not think it is helpful, either, to refer to the possibility of profits being repatriated overseas.

ANSWER.PARA: On what information is available to me, this is not a situation where some foreign company is taking money out of Australia and waxing fat on it. The fact is that the International Harvester parent company as well as its Australian subsidiary is in difficulty. I do not think it is a case where a surplus of assets is stashed away somewhere which would amount to some abuse of the position of the employers in Australia. I understand the reasoning behind the question. It is proper for us to be concerned about the position of those employers. It is proper for us to be concerned about the position of suppliers and other people who are probably creditors of the company and who would similarly have welfare problems in the event of obligations not being met. In all of these cases where substantial commercial concerns run at a difficulty and that difficulty is real, it is unlikely that the problem can be solved by some mere legislative change. The point raised is a serious one and I will see that the relevant Ministers get a chance to consider it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE: IMPOSITION OF LEVY BY VICTORIAN GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Health consider that the Federal Government is right to intervene on behalf of taxpayers in Victoria over the Victorian Government's levy on health insurance? Is this State levy intended to streamline the process of payments for services for out- patients in hospitals? Is it also true that the levy of 40c a week for single persons and 80c a week for families is roughly double the cost of meeting health funds' liabilities for out-patient services? Could this money be raised more fairly and effectively in other ways?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the move by the Victorian Government to impose and collect a levy, as has been set out by Senator Hamer. I am also aware of the fact that despite the professed purpose of the levy to finance out-patient services in Victoria, the levy will in fact collect twice the cost of the liability which the funds have for the services which are rendered. In other words, the Victorian Government cannot claim that it is using the levy simply to recoup the costs of providing the services; it is using it also as a general revenue raising measure. This was referred to in some of the newspapers. I note that the Age newspaper in its editorial acknowledged that that is one of the purposes. The levy is to a significant degree a fund raising exercise by the Victorian Government for the hospitals in that State. It is an imposition which it is imposing upon people who contribute to health insurance in Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth Government believes it is essential to take action to protect the insured public and taxpayers against excessive health cost increases wherever they occur. The Government believes it has a responsibility under its insurance powers to protect the interests of contributors. In this case, with the levy being in excess of what can be reasonably put down as the cost of the services provided, it is our view that the only way to protect the rights of contributors is to oppose the levy. We believe, in any event, that general levies do not represent the best way of going about recovering the cost of delivering these services. We observe that the Victorian Government has failed to collect charges from insured patients for out-patient services at the point where the services are given. This is something for which the Victorian Government itself must answer. The imposition of an excessive levy in the way which is being proposed is one which will disadvantage those who contribute to health insurance funds in Victoria. It is for that reason that my colleague has made the announcement that he has. The Commonwealth will seek to take action to prevent this occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to the Environment Protection ( Impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the object of which is to ensure that matters affecting the environment, to a significant extent, are properly examined and taken into account in decisions and actions involving the Commonwealth Government. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that under this legislation the Minister may direct that an environment impact study be prepared? Is it also a fact that under this legislation during 1981-82, the last financial year, proposals were assessed by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment in respect of airport developments at Darwin, Adelaide and Perth? In respect of the Government's unilateral decision to construct a parallel runway at Sydney ( Kingsford-Smith) Airport, is the Minister prepared to direct that before any work takes place an environment impact study should be prepared of the proposed works and that such study be made the subject of review by interested members of the public and community and local government organisations which are vitally involved and affected by the decision?

—The recent announcement by my colleague Mr Fife that a parallel runway would be developed at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was taken after careful and prolonged discussion with all involved parties, including the State of New South Wales. Mr Fife made it quite clear in that announcement that what was being proposed was in fact a package of proposals of which the parallel runway proposal was seen as being one part. The honourable senator asked his question in relation to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974. I believe the honourable senator is correct in saying that the Minister has power under that Act to direct that environmental impact statements shall be prepared. I do not have the Act in front of me but I have no reason to doubt that that is so. Whether there was a proposal before the Minister that environmental impact statements should be prepared in respect of airport developments can be answered only by Mr McVeigh. I shall seek to obtain that information for Senator McClelland.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. What redress or protection is there for patients left with bills when medical benefits payments are refused, with the support of the Department of Health, on grounds of over-servicing when such tests were not at the patient's request?
—I am not sure that the situation set out by Senator Watson has actually occurred.
—It has.

—It has? It might be helpful if Senator Watson provided any details of any of his constituents for whom medical benefit payments or rebates for medical services have not been provided. If he provided those, and advice of the circumstances in which they occurred, I would be happy to pass them on to the Minister concerned to see whether we can have each of those cases examined.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. A short time ago the Minister answered a question about the increase in the cost of power in New South Wales. I ask: Is the Minister aware that the price of power in South Australia has almost doubled since the Tonkin Government came to office? Can the Minister give a reason for the increase which is similar to that which he gave in the case of New South Wales? How can the Minister claim that only State Labor governments raise prices when the Tonkin Liberal Government increased hospital charges from $40 to $105 a day, excess water rates from 24c to 37c for 1,000 litres, bread from 60c to 85c a loaf and every other government charge proportionately? Further, is the Minister aware that the Tonkin Government has sold a great proportion of government assets acquired by the former Labor Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said before regarding the New South Wales Government's cost of electric power is, in fact, quite correct. Recent surveys have shown that the price of industrial electric power in New South Wales is astronomical, not only in Australian terms but also because it is regarded as being amongst the highest in the free world. That is a record that is hard to keep up with. That statement has to be made against the background of what I said earlier. Since Senator Elstob has reminded me, I pointed out that the Wran Government went to the electors on the price of its electricity and the availability of excess electricity supply. It said two things: First, that in New South Wales electricity was the cheapest in Australia and would remain so and that is demonstrably wrong; secondly, that New South Wales, if it elected a Wran government, would have a great capacity to produce excess electricity and thus would be able to create full employment by attracting additional manufacturers who were electricity consumers. In fact, the very reverse is true. New South Wales could not operate its installed capacity and did not have any excess electricity at all. What I said is abundantly right. The fact of the matter is that, in contrast to that, the Tonkin Government has gone out to get industries, is showing that it is able to attract industry and is showing that it is able to draw from the Cooper Basin the condensates by pipeline to establish a petro-chemical industry in Whyalla.
—It has the highest unemployment on the mainland and 8,000 people a year are leaving the State.
—Again, honourable senators opposite do not like to hear the constructive things that are happening.
—They don't like to hear distortions of fact. That is what we don't like.

—There is no distortion of fact when I state that there is a pipeline coming from Cooper Basin to Stony Point, that it will in fact be capable of bringing to Stony Point condensate in terms of something up to 35,000 to 40,000 barrels a day without pressure and 80,000 barrels a day under pressure . That is a great new potential for South Australia. Honourable senators opposite do not like to hear about the potential opening up at Roxby Downs which is potentially one of the greatest mining areas in the world. They do not like to hear every day and every week of a new discovery of some kind of minerals in South Australia. They do not like to hear of the vigorous actions of the South Australian Liberal Government in attracting industry.
—Have you got rid of your shares yet?
—Order! The Leader of the Government will resume his seat. You will withdraw that remark, Senator Walsh. That was most offensive. You will withdraw it unconditionally and immediately.
—What did I say, Mr President?
—You know exactly what you said, Senator. You said: 'Have you sold your shares yet'.
—I said: 'Have you got rid of them yet?'
—I ask you to withdraw unconditionally.
—I will withdraw it.
—You will use the word 'withdraw', not the words 'will withdraw'. There are no conditions on this; you withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you.
—Lest Senator Walsh think that by that contrivance, that having intruded some kind of misinformation he can--

—I raise a point of order. Senator Walsh has withdrawn unconditionally. I do not think it is right that the Leader of the Government should continue his disparaging remarks in that way after a withdrawal has been given by Senator Walsh.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call the Leader of the Government.

—In the course of my answer to a question, an interjection occurred. The interjection contrived to make some insinuations. Have I sold my shares yet? I have no shares at all and have had no shares at all during my Ministry. Let that be perfectly clear. This kind of insinuation is done as a trick method because Senator Walsh thinks-he has done this in the past -that if he withdraws, a little bit of mud will stick.

—I raise a point of order. The accusation of a 'trick method' being used by an honourable senator imputes, to my knowledge, a matter of deceit or connivance to trick the Senate. I ask that that allegation be withdrawn.

—Order! There is no point of order, Senator. The remark that was made by Senator Walsh was extremely offensive. We have heard the word 'Rundle' mentioned often in interjections in this place until, finally, an interjection was made which implied that one of the Ministers in this place held shares. The Minister was merely responding to that. He regarded it as an offensive remark made by an honourable senator in this place. There is no point of order. I call the Leader of the Government.
—But the Minister can say what he likes!

—Order! In response to Senator Robertson, the Minister is not allowed to say what he likes. The Minister has been making reference to the fact -he has been clearing up a point-that he has had no shares. I would suggest that , if any such accusation is made about any honourable senator in this place, the Chair would allow that honourable senator to respond and clear his or her name. A withdrawal is one thing but an insinuation to the outside world is another. I again call the Leader of the Government.

—I wish to clarify this matter. In the whole of my lifetime, the only shares that I have had of any kind at all are some hundreds of shares I bought at 10c each but which died because I could not keep them alive when they were raised to 20c each. I repeat, in case the insinuations are there: I have never had any Rundle shares or any other shares other than one very slight venture quite some years ago-10 or 20 years ago. I have no shares. I have no interests at all. Nor is my family in any shareholding situation. That interjection was made because, in response to Senator Elstob, I was pointing out that in contrast to the Australian Labor Party the South Australian Government of today has developed a vigorous approach to attracting new industries. I repeat: The opening of Roxby Downs, with its great potential, the identification of new mineral findings in recent times and the identification recently of some potentially useful coal deposits are all good news for South Australia. The South Australian Government is vigorously pursuing these things in the face of a Labor Opposition which aims to stop Roxby Downs and to stop uranium enrichment and which is out to see that the people of South Australia do not benefit from its great potential. I think it bodes very badly for Senator Elstob to try to compare South Australia with New South Wales. In fact, the election promises of the Wran Government are totally in tatters.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister did not give me the reason for the increases in hospital charges, water charges and many other charges.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether that is a supplementary question . Senator Elstob made a series of statements in asking his question. I do not know whether they are correct. I will look at them and if they beg a reply I will see that the information is given to him.

—Has the Minister for Education noted an article in the Australian of 22 September in which it was alleged: More teaching jobs are available for physics graduates than there are people to fill them; that some government departments have not been able to fill permanent jobs and there is also an acute shortage of qualified physics teachers in all States; and that some departments of education have even started advertising for teachers? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the above allegations are correct? If so, what action has his Department taken to overcome the shortage?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lajovic asked, first, whether I am aware of certain general concerns that have been expressed. I am aware of them. Indeed, they are the subject of discussion and comment by Ministers for Education when they meet at the Australian Education Council. The training and preparation of teachers within any State are, of course, primarily responsibilities which that State bears although we, through the colleges of advanced education and the major role they have in teacher training, have a major interest as well.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators will be aware that changes are going on in the demography of Australian school students. We have a reducing number of students in the primary school sector while we still have an increasing number of students in the secondary sector, although we expect that that will level out and the demography will change over the next decade. Even within the secondary school sector changes are occurring in terms of both subject preference-the kinds of offerings which are available-and the priorities which are given by schools as to subjects which should be taught. The problem which colleges of advanced education face in planning their course offerings for training teachers and, I suppose, the problem which State authorities face is that the lead times involved-the time between the taking of a decision that more or less of a certain kind of teacher is needed and the time those teachers actually become available-are quite considerable. I think the State authorities have considerable difficulties in planning these things. I can assure Senator Lajovic , however, that they are aware of the issue and the difficulties and that considerable efforts are being made by the State authorities and the colleges of advanced education, which have the responsibility for training teachers, to try to get some better consonance between the need for teachers in particular subjects and the kind of training which is occurring. Having said all that, I have no doubt that there will be some shortages of particular subject teachers. As priorities change in the future, those shortages will continue to appear here and there within the sectors.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and follows the answer he just gave to Senator Elstob. I refer to the Minister's personal declaration of pecuniary interest which he made in the course of that answer. I assume the declaration was made in pursuit of the interests of the Ministry and of the Government. I ask: Why do not all Ministers declare their pecuniary interests in the same public and open way as he just did? Does he agree that the interests of the Government would be served if they did? Will he urge that course upon his colleagues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Button may well recollect that earlier, in my portfolio as Minister for National Development and Energy, I made it abundantly clear-of course, Senator Walsh knew that; he was only trying to take a smart trick today-that I held no shares.
—No, no.

—He did. It is in Hansard. I made that abundantly clear . The little boy who thinks he has been awfully naughty and is standing in the corner, grins. But the fact is that, as a Minister holding a portfolio that relates to national development and energy, I ought not to hold any shares in resources. I have said so. Indeed, I have acted accordingly and I have also indicated that the same applies to my wife. That was known. Equally, Senator Button will know that what I have said before with regard to pecuniary interests is in fact taking place. The Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest was set up and it made a report. All of its recommendations with regard to Ministers are being imposed upon Ministers at this moment.
—A secret disclosure to the Prime Minister.

—Secret society. I wonder whether the Labor Party front bench spokesmen on resources will declare voluntarily, as I have done, their holdings in shares. I wonder whether Senator Button will invite those who sit on the front bench of the Labor Party to make a public declaration. It is very easy to look at others. I repeat that with regard to pecuniary interests relating to its Ministers, this Government has adopted in full the Bowen Committee recommendations. That has been carried out. I made the statement because I believe it is important that nobody should be able to insinuate anything and nobody should have any reason to suspect that the decisions that I may recommend or take on behalf of the Government have any self-interest. They have none.
—I ask the Minister a supplementary question. Does he not regard the high standard which he sets himself as being appropriate to other Ministers in the Fraser Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard Mr Justice Bowen as a man of great probity and of great judicial judgment. He and his colleagues on the Bowen Committee made recommendations based upon the principles of probity and integrity. It was he and his Committee that regarded the very standards that we have adopted as being proper in terms of probity and integrity. We have adopted them. In the past others have not.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that in 1979 the United States Post Office issued a stamp entitled 'Honouring Vietnam Veterans' commemorating servicemen in the Vietnam War? Is the Minister also aware that, while Australia Post has issued stamps with themes of both world wars, it has not issued stamps commemorating the services of Australians in either Korea or Vietnam? Can the Minister say whether a stamp or series of stamps depicting aspects of Australia's involvement in both of these conflicts would fall within the guidelines for designs on Australian postage stamps? If so, can the Minister say whether the theme could be considered for an appropriate future stamp issue?

—I am advised that Senator Crichton-Browne is correct, that the United States Post Office did issue a stamp in 1979 honouring Vietnam veterans, as he set out. I am also advised that he is correct when he says that whilst Australia Post has issued stamps with themes on both world wars, it has not done so on Korea or Vietnam. I am advised that he is correct because those stamps were issued by what was the Postmaster-General's Department. He then asked whether the Minister could say whether a stamp or series of stamps would fall within the guidelines and if so whether we could do something about it. They would fall within Australia Post guidelines for stamp issue, but the general rule covering anniversaries of events which may be commemorated are those of not under 50 years ago or multiples of 50 years. That is just the working rule of thumb on which Australia Post operates in the issue of commemorative stamps. Commemorative pre-stamped envelopes, on the other hand, can be issued within 25 years or multiples of 25 years. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Communications and ask him whether he will draw this matter to the attention of Australia Post in case it can give more favourable consideration to Senator Crichton-Browne's suggestion.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that in the latest Budget, allocations for public housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement rose by only $70.7m? Is it also the case that in the last three years the total rental stock held by State housing authorities rose 7 per cent but that the waiting list for public housing rose by 26.5 per cent over the same period? At a time when young people are facing skyrocketing rents and a housing shortage, is that not a gross abdication of the Government's responsibility in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not. The increase in the Commonwealth direct funding for housing under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement this year was of the order of $70m-an increase of 27 per cent. At the same time, the Commonwealth at the time of the Premiers Conference indicated that the States would receive the ability to use a greater proportion of their works and housing program loan funds at a concessional rate of interest. The Commonwealth indicated to the States that if they chose to divert further expenditure into that area the works and housing money so diverted would be made available to the States at the concessional interest rates payable under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The interest rate is 4.5 per cent per annum and the money is repayable over 53 years. It is certainly a very low interest rate.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to say that those Commonwealth initiatives taken and announced at the time of the Premiers Conference are reflected in very real improvements in the levels of State expenditure in the welfare housing area. The figures are not before me at the moment, but in one State there was an increase of 80 per cent plus in expenditure and a whole series of States have taken advantage of the Commonwealth's offer.

In the Senate last week I incorporated in Hansard a table showing the expenditure by the Commonwealth and States over a 10-year period. That table, which is accessible to all honourable senators, shows that over a period of years there has been a decline in the amount of Commonwealth funding going into the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Contemporaneously, of course, there has been a considerable increase in State funds. That reflects the attitude of this Government, which is to free up the general revenue payments to the States and to leave the States with a higher discretion as to what expenditure they undertake. The increase in Commonwealth funding in the current financial year- the additional incentive that we gave in respect of loan funds-shows expenditure this year to be at a very high rate both in real terms and in money terms in comparison with the last 10 years. I am satisfied that there will be a very considerable effort in the housing field overall during this financial year. The Commonwealth's changes were in recognition of the fact that there has been an increase in the waiting list and that there is an increased housing problem. That is certainly acknowledged by me and by the Government.

I should mention that it is not merely in that area that the Commonwealth has housing responsibilities. If one looks at the other programs that we undertake, such as the aged and disabled housing program, the Homeless Persons Assistance Act and emergency accommodation for families, one will find in each case substantial funds-in most cases substantially increased funds-again in recognition of what is seen as a more difficult housing situation. The Commonwealth's efforts are also not restricted to the welfare housing area. I briefly mention the very considerable concessions made in the housing area generally in the housing package announced in March and in the Budget decisions which involved an extension of assistance for home buyers to bridge the deposit gap and of course the very welcome introduction of tax deductibility for interest in excess of 10 per cent. So, across a whole range of measures, the Commonwealth has acknowledged the tightness and difficulty in the housing market and we certainly are seeing signs that those Commonwealth measures are having a positive effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Australian National Director of Community Aid Abroad charged at a CAA convention in Melbourne that Australian aid programs have not reached the poor of the Third World countries and that Australian funding is directed to those countries that are more important to Australia's security. It was further stated that Australia would get better value if non- government agencies, rather than government authorities, handled the distribution of aid. Having in mind the very substantial funding Australia has committed to assist oppressed countries, I ask: Does the Government accept the criticism of CAA? Is it considered that action is necessary to improve distribution of such aid that is the responsibility of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government has seen the reports of Mr Martin concerning Australian overseas aid. It is most unfortunate that he does not understand the basis on which Australia or any other Western country provides development assistance.
—He does, only too well.

— Development projects funded under an official aid program must be conducted on a government to government basis and each government has certain responsibilities. The donor must acknowledge the right of the recipient to determine its own development priorities and to exercise control over the allocation of development funds and aid resources. The donor is not without influence in shaping the nature and scope of projects to achieve consistency in its aid policies and to ensure responsible expenditure of what are, after all, public moneys; but, in exercising such influence; we must be careful lest our activities be seen or resented by the recipient government as an unwarranted interference in its internal affairs. The Australian Government has particular responsibilities to provide aid to our regional neighbours. In all our aid to these and other countries, we attempt to strike a balance between activities that promote growth and those that help the poorest sectors of the community. Despite the comment made earlier from the Opposition, it is recognised that the aid we give to other countries has been effective and of assistance. We have a very strong commitment to continue overseas aid in the manner in which we have conducted it in the past.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources and refers to a $97,000 Export Market Development Grant payment made in 1978-79. Does the Minister know that the Export Development Grants Board Chairman stated that it was paid to Westwools Pty Ltd, a company sent to the bottom-of-the-harbour by the Maher organisation in 1976, but that the former Chairman of Westwools Pty Ltd has stated that the money was paid to Westwools Holdings? Which of these conflicting versions is correct? To which company was the cheque made out? Was the cheque paid into an account? If so, what account?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In case one thinks that my response in particularity is to a Dorothy Dix question, let me say that it happens to be true because Senator Walsh gave my office notice of the particularities of his question. Therefore, I have a brief before me in that regard. The Government has had a look at the matter that has been raised. I am advised that the Minister is satisfied that the Export Development Grants Board and the Department of Trade and Resources have acted fully in accordance with the export market development grants legislation. The firm of Westwools Pty Ltd submitted a claim for EMDG in respect of the period 1 July 1976 to 30 June 1977. The Board investigated whether the claimant had a grant entitlement and in August 1978 determined a grant of $97, 034. Subsequent to the determination, the Department arranged in the usual manner, through the Department of Finance, for a cheque for $97,034 to be sent on 26 September 1978 to Westwools Pty Ltd, the company that had incurred the eligible expenditure in 1976-77. Under EMDG legislation, once the Board has determined a grant entitlement, the claimant has a legal right to be paid by the Commonwealth. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill is one of several measures designed to give effect to the new diesel fuel duty rebate arrangements foreshadowed by my colleague the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his Budget speech on 17 August 1982. On and from 8 p.m. on that date the existing diesel fuel certificate scheme, wherein certificates were issued to purchasers of diesel fuel for 'off road' use to obtain the fuel at duty free prices, will be terminated. In its place this Bill will introduce a new rebate system which will require all purchases of diesel fuel to be made at the duty paid price with rebates payable to persons in certain categories for their 'off road' use. The relevant customs and excise by-laws which provided the authority for the issuance of diesel fuel certificates under the previous scheme were revoked on 17 August 1982.

The Bill contains amendments to a number of pieces of legislation, including amendments to the Diesel Fuel Taxation (Administration) Act 1957, to terminate the operation of that Act on and from 8 p.m. on 17 August. Any purchases of diesel fuel for 'off road' use made at duty free rates under the certificate scheme, up to 8 p.m. on 17 August, will remain subject to the end use provisions of that act. Similarly, purchasers who, before 8 p.m. on 17 August, purchased diesel fuel at duty inclusive prices and used that fuel for 'off road' purposes will be entitled to rebates as provided for under the old arrangements. The Bill also amends the Customs Act and the Excise Act to introduce new provisions into both of those Acts relating to the new rebate system.

I will now outline some of the details of the new rebate system. As from 8 p.m. on 17 August all diesel fuel sales have been at a price inclusive of the duty. This means that no users of diesel fuel have been able to purchase, as they did in the past, duty free diesel fuel from oil companies, agencies or distributors. The users of diesel fuel in the categories defined in clause 5 of the Bill who purchase the fuel for their 'off road' purposes are, however, eligible for a rebate of the duty paid on the diesel fuel used in their operations.

To simplify the claiming process an amendment was made in the other place to enable persons to claim a rebate immediately after they have purchased the fuel for the specified uses. Previously they would have been required to use the fuel before a rebate application could be lodged. To obtain the rebate a user must lodge an application with a Collector of Customs. It is proposed that payments of the rebate will be made on the basis of the estimated proportion of the fuel proposed to be used for the specified purposes.

Domestic users may claim a rebate at any time. Amendments were made in the other place to enable other than domestic users to claim a rebate after three months of a previous claim or after 1000 litres of fuel have been purchased. 1000 litres is equivalent to a rebate of $62 at the current rate of duty. This change was made to benefit small users of the fuel, particularly those users engaged in primary production.

The categories I referred to earlier relate to the use of the fuel in agriculture, mining, forestry and fishing applications, in domestic premises, hospitals, aged persons' homes, and nursing homes. So as not to disadvantage sawmills located outside a forest, amendments were also made in the other place to extend the rebate eligibility to milling operations carried on at a sawmill located outside a forest or plantation including the transport of timber, other than on a public road, to those sawmills. Previously rebate was restricted to forestry milling and to the processing of timber in a forest or plantation. A further amendment was made to make it clear that fuel used in providing domestic lighting for residential premises will be eligible for the rebate.

Because of the revised criteria whereby rebates will be paid on purchases of diesel fuel for use, rather than on amounts of fuel used, in the defined categories, amendments were also made in the other place to include provision for the recovery of rebates paid to a person in circumstances where the person initially purchases the fuel for use in the defined categories but subsequently uses that fuel in some other manner. Claims for the rebate will be processed after the date upon which the amending legislation receives the Royal Assent and it is proposed to amend the customs and excise regulations to set out the requirements relating to applications for the rebate and to the procedures for claiming rebates.

The Bill contains certain investigative powers similar to the powers contained in the Diesel Fuel Taxation (Administration) Act. These powers are essential for the protection of the revenue and for the effective administration of the new rebate system. It is expected that rebates paid to claimants under the new scheme will amount to approximately $112m per annum. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill gives effect to most of the social security and welfare measures which were in the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) two months ago. In the view of the Opposition-and, I believe, of the general public-those measures give little joy to pensioners, to the unemployed or to low income families. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) promised, as expressed in the Governor-General's Speech of 17 February 1976: 'The Government will not permit economic recovery to take place at the expense of those who are less well off.' That promise was never kept. Economic recovery has not taken place. Economic conditions have not been worse since the Depression of the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes that have taken place have improved the lot of high income earners, particularly by way of tax frauds, while the less well off have suffered. Year by year pensioners have found that their pension has declined in relation to average weekly earnings. The Prime Minister, in his 1975 election speech, said: 'The real value of pensions will be preserved.' Pensioners know better. Under Labor they saw pensions rise from 19.7 per cent of average weekly earnings, which it had been under the McMahon Government, to almost 24 per cent. The pension rose twice as fast as the cost of living. But under this Government, the Fraser Government, the pension has dropped to under 22 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Prime Minister, in his 1977 election speech, said:
We have taken politics out of the pension increases by linking them automatically with the consumer price index.

That must be news indeed to pensioners. Under successive Fraser governments the pensioners have become more political than ever before. Every senator and member of this Parliament knows that the pensioners are increasingly angry and increasingly militant because this Government has taken it for granted that, by indexing pensions to cost of living rises based on a consumer price index five months out of date, it can then forget about the pensioners.

The single pension is currently $5 a week below the poverty line. The pension of a widow or deserted wife with three children is almost $25 a week below the poverty line. This legislation will give a small rise, but it will be swallowed up by rent increases and sales tax rises so that they will get no overall benefit from it and their pensions will still be below what Professor Henderson called an 'austere' poverty line. The poorest pensioners, the 451,000 pensioners on supplementary assistance-that is, people who have almost no other income and who pay rent-will get out of this Budget only the $3.10 a week which relates to cost increases they have been paying for the last five months and $2 towards increased rent. These payments are extraordinarily mean. It is no wonder that pensioners are demonstrating increasingly against the Government. The Opposition is pleased to see that the legislation is being amended so that a person in receipt of a wife's pension who is overseas when her husband dies can qualify for a widow's pension without having to return to Australia. I should point out that my colleague Senator Grimes has made several representations about this.

I would now like to make some comments on some of the specific provisions of the legislation. First, I refer to clause 77 which applies to the unemployment benefit. It is evident from the Government's discriminatory treatment of the unemployed that it still blames them rather than itself for the appallingly high rate of unemployment in this country. Although the benefit for the single adult unemployed is being increased it is being taken only to half the married rate and probably is reaching that only because this highly moralistic Government is embarrassed that many of the unemployed are claiming de facto relationships because it pays them more than taking a single status.

I ask honourable senators to consider that the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat report of poverty measurement has stated that increased unemployment has increased the numbers below the poverty line and that the extent of poverty is now markedly greater for the non-aged single persons who are unemployed. The number of unemployed receiving the adult single rate benefit grew to 264,000 last May-it would, of course, be much higher now. Of those 264,000 some 262,000 people had no income apart from the $58.10, which is $21 a week below the poverty line. I am sure honourable senators will agree with me that it is this country's shame to have so many unemployed. It is this country's shame that those victims of government policy are treated so badly by wealthy Cabinet Ministers. The Government is increasing the rate, but only to $64.40 which, again, will be close to $20 below the poverty line.

I remind the Senate that this single rate applies also to special beneficiaries whom we are seeing in increasing numbers as more claimants are refused invalid pension and sickness benefits. I remind the Senate that several thousand of these special beneficiaries are single women who have given up work to look after sick or aged parents and are paid well below the poverty line for this selfless work. The unemployment benefit for the single junior and adult unemployed is the only income support payment which is not indexed. The Government has made a moral judgment that they are less worthy or less significant than pensioners and a political judgment that the public agrees with it and that it can get away with this despicable meanness to the unemployed.

I refer now to some of the other discriminations against the unemployed. They are not given rent assistance which pensioners receive. If they are unlucky enough to have an accident or to fall ill their sickness benefit rate will not include the supplementary allowance. They are given no fringe benefits except the health card. They get no assistance with mortgage payments, rate payments, travel, car registration, hearing aids, spectacles, dental treatment-the list goes on. They face the same costs as other families but they are given no compensation for the cost of living rises and no assistance in the rental market .

I turn now to the token rise of $4 a week for the young unemployed. All that can be said about that is that it is an insulting and heartless measure. Their parents cannot keep them on that amount if they themselves are unemployed or poor. Living away from home on that amount of money is an absolute disaster. I think it is particularly disappointing to honourable senators in this place that the Government's decision on the young unemployed was so heartless because a committee of the Senate undertook a very thorough investigation into the circumstances of homeless youth.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did it recommend?

—It made many recommendations which have not been incorporated in the Budget, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) would know. The family income supplement has been introduced in some European countries, including Britain. On 24 August this year, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ) said that his Government introduced the family income supplement-not a Labor government or a socialist government. He knows very well that the family income supplement was an Australian Labor Party proposal which was announced by us in May 1980. The Liberal Party, which had scorned the Labor proposal at that time, took over the name and the principle, amending it only so as to pay as little as possible. Instead of hundreds of thousands of families with children being eligible, no more than 30,000 families in Australia are expected to be able to take it up. That is the difference between the two parties, a difference in a genuine concern for low income families by the Labor Party and a stingy tokenism by the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's supplement will help at most 30,000 families and yet the Prime Minister has had the hide to call it the most far-sighted reform since the introduction of family allowances. If that is the most far-sighted reform this Government has been capable of, no wonder it is in the chaotic state that it is and no wonder its credibility is as low as it is. It is to be kept to working families where the breadwinners earn below award wages, unless there are five or more children where the breadwinner can earn award wages or a few dollars over. The average weighted minimum weekly wage last July was $229. In the past two years, that wage has risen by 11 per cent a year, so we would expect the minimum wage, when the family income supplement is introduced next May, to be over $250 a week. This means that single income families, with the breadwinner on a minimum award wage, would have to have four dependent children to get any benefit at all. This small proportion of families would be mainly single females whose awards are lower, under award workers and a few farmers and self-employed persons whose incomes are at or can be brought down to that level.

We also remind the Senate that the Prime Minister boasted that the Budget would benefit a family earning $300 a week with two children and a mortgage of $25,000 by about $17 or $18 a week. He even called it a 'fairly typical situation'. The truth is that such families represent fewer than 0.8 per cent of Australian families. It will come as no suprise to the general public to realise that the Prime Minister is so erroneous in his concept of what the average family is and what it earns. The family income supplement will be paid to families who are eligible for disadvantaged health cards, reinforcing the poverty stigma. We all remember that, although this Government was willing to spend millions on advertising middle class housing benefits at the time of the Victorian election, it refused to spend more than a few thousand dollars on radio to inform people of their rights to health care cards. I doubt whether we will see a sizable promotion budget for the family income supplement because the Government saves money where there is a low uptake.

I would like at this stage to point out that the minimum wage figures quoted on page 30 of the explanatory notes are misleading and, in our view, seriously and deliberately misleading. The notional minimum wage, as quoted in the national wage case, bears no relation to minimum wage awards, as Senator Chaney well knows. The explanatory notes give a notional weekly wage of $140.30 in May 1982. The actual weighted minimum award weekly wage in May 1982 was $221.18. I believe that the Minister should be condemned for this attempt to mislead the Parliament and the public.

The other point to be made about tying the family health income supplement to the disadvantaged persons health card is that the health card is not indexed to the consumer price index as is the pension rate. It is increased by around only 70 per cent and so falls further back in relation to price movements each six months. This means that many people on low wages who qualified for the family income supplement could in the following six months find that because their wages had been increased by the CPI they had become ineligible for the family income supplement because those levels had risen by only 70 per cent of the CPI. What a way to penalise a family!

Family allowances are to be increased for the first two children for the first time since 1976 but the real value of those allowances is still far below the value of eight years ago. A family with two children will receive $10.25 a month less than if those family allowances had kept pace with inflation. Every group in the country concerned with poverty and welfare has urged the Government to increase family allowances and it has taken it seven years to respond. Even the Government's own report on poverty measurements stated:

Couples with children are more likely than those without to have low income in relation to needs while sole parents are among the neediest of groups. There are more couples with one or two children with low income in relation to their needs than couples with three children or more.

If the family allowance had been indexed, a family with five children would be $ 398.40 a year better off. If the family allowance had been indexed, the Fraser Government would be outlaying another $396m this year.

It is important to point out that the slight improvement in the income test for the unemployed, the sick and special beneficiaries is token only. There are so few beneficiaries who can find part time or casual work that there is no reason to penalise them by imposing a far harsher means test than is imposed on pensioners. They are paid less; they get no indexation, no concessions; and, if they do find work, they are allowed to keep less of their earnings than pensioners. On 6 September 1976, the Prime Minister said:
Those who are economically disadvantaged through no fault of their own should be able to look to Governments for assistance.
But his actions indicate that the Government gives as little assistance as possible.

It is important to point out that the increase in personal care subsidy is only the second increase since 1974. The first was early in 1980. The subsidy is now about the same value as it was when Labor took it to $60 a month in 1974. The Joint Working Party on Hostel Accommodation made many recommendations in 1979 which have not yet been implemented. It also pointed out that the decline in the value of the age pension could not assist the financing of services expected in hostels. Significant losses were being made by hostels in most States. Senator Chaney put Mr Hodges in charge of a study of the aged legislation and procedures , but the ludicrous secrecy with which this was done meant that the Parliament still has no idea what recommendations were made by the then Liberal back bencher who had access to departmental facilities as well as interest groups. There was no good reason for not releasing this report to the Parliament and it is a bad precedent.

It is our view that the mobility allowance recognises that transport is a major cost option for disabled people who are unable to use public transport. It will be welcomed by members of the disabled community and, as a concept, it is welcomed by the Opposition. Our concern-it is a serious one-is about the restrictions imposed on eligibility. It is hard to see how people are going to qualify to make use of the $18m allocated for a full year's operation. The major eligibility condition is that recipients must be engaged in gainful employment, including sheltered employment, for at least 20 hours a week. Many people will be excluded by this provision. What about disabled people who are looking for work? They are to be punished, as are the non-disabled unemployed, instead of being assisted and encouraged to help themselves. It is a mistake to think that, if they cannot find open employment, there is always sheltered employment to fall bank on. Sheltered workshops have long waiting lists. What about disabled people for whom gainful employment is not an option? For instance what about women who are fully occupied caring for families and others who are too severely disabled to contemplate employment? Once again the Government's obsession with the work ethic forces these people to depend on charity or not to go out unless they have resources of their own. The requirement that gainful employment be undertaken for at least 20 hours a week is out of line with conditions for the sheltered employment allowance, which is payable to a person working 18 hours a week over three days, although the person must be working towards full time employment. This kind of anomaly-a mean one at that-should not be countenanced at the introduction of an important measure.

I am aware that there are other honourable senators who wish to participate in the debate. The Opposition has many reservations and many concerns about the measures before us. However, because of the measures in the Bill that we do support and because we recognise the urgency of making available as early as possible those few measures of assistance to the potential beneficiaries, we do not oppose this legislation.
