We do not yet know what it will be in May next year but it is linked to the health card for disadvantaged persons. It is being brought in particularly to overcome the anomalies that exist at the moment whereby those with large families on low incomes do not receive the same income as unemployed people can get by way of extra assistance for each child. The cut-off point tapers off. It has been reduced on the basis of $1 for every $2 income over the amount. Pharmaceutical concessions have been given to those disadvantaged groups. Families on low incomes with a health card will now have to pay only $2 for each item. Previously such people were stretched considerably to pay their chemist bills. They have also been helped quite considerably in the housing assistance area. The family man-the single income earner-will now benefit considerably from that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the subject of age pensions. From 1 November the single pension rate will be $154.50 per fortnight and the married rate will be $257.60 a fortnight. The income which a single pensioner can earn has been increased from $20 a week to $30 a week. Now a single pensioner can earn $30 a week. Pensioners have been asking for this for quite some time and I was delighted to see that come in. The married rate has been increased from $34.50 to $50 a week. As I say, this has been greeted as very laudable by the pensioners' unions. The pension now does not cut out until the single pensioner has an income of $184.50. A married couple can earn $307.60 before the pension cuts out completely. Fringe benefits have been extended to sickness beneficiaries. The income limits for pensioner fringe benefits and health cards have been increased. The single rate has risen to $54 and the married rate to $90.

Again, pensioners benefit from the personal tax reductions, but they have an additional $250 rebate-that is the maximum-so a pensioner does not start paying tax now until his total income, including pension, reaches $5,429, and this again has been welcomed very greatly by pensioners. Indeed, between the figure that I have just given, $5,429 and $7,429, the tax rate is only 12 1/2 per cent, and it is not until after the figure of $7,429 a year that pensioners will pay the same as other people-30c in the dollar. Senator Ryan seemed to be indicating that the Government had been-to use her word-stingy in its social security benefits. I feel that the people of Australia have indicated where they stand about that, and I think that Senator Ryan is trying to draw a long bow.

As I said, pharmaceutical concessions that apply to the disadvantaged groups also apply to all pensioners. The position of the pensioner who at present has the fringe benefits and does not pay anything for his drugs will remain the same , but the concessional rate of $2 per item will be available to all pensioners, no matter what their financial situation is.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are on the health legislation again.

—It is all to do with social welfare. For aged accommodation and disabled accommodation, $170m is being spent over the next two years-$83m this year, a considerable additional expenditure by the Government. Senior citizen centres are having an additional $7m this year-$14m in the next two years. Rental assistance will be further increased by $2 a week in the Budget, a rise of $5 a week just in this year. The rental assistance for pensioners is now $10 a week. We have been congratulated about the personal care subsidy, as I have found as I have visited nursing homes over the last couple of weeks. It has been increased by $10, from $20 to $30, for all eligible people in hostel-type accommodation. Indeed, it was backdated to July 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan said that there was a paltry increase from $36 to $40 for the under-18s. I underline the fact that in our Committee, which produced a unanimous report, the Opposition did not go for large increases in that $36. It was agreed in our Committee that we believed the $36 that was given last year was only a subsidy for the under-18 living within the family home. I believe that the $40 to which the Government has now increased the payment is still that -just a subsidy for the under-18 living within the family home. After all, someone who is under 18 is still the responsibility of the parents. We find that this is so in other legislation. Regarding people under 18 who, for one reason or another, have to go away from their family home or who are unable to live there and who become homeless youth, which my Committee was investigating, the Government has already earmarked $300,000 as interim assistance for that group of youth. The benefit for over-18 unemployed who are without dependants has also risen by $6.30 to $64.40 a week. The income test for unemployment and sickness benefits has also been increased to $10. This again is tapered to a $60 a week benefit. I now go on to assistance to the handicapped. Perhaps I may read a sentence from one letter that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney, received from the Association of Sheltered Workshops of New South Wales. The last sentence is:
We believe that the improvements referred to are most commendable and thank you for them.

That is the sort of letter that Senator Chaney was getting. Assistance to the handicapped has been considerable. First, an income test-free health card has been given to handicapped people, invalid pensioners, for 12 months. If they decide that they want to try to get themselves a job that they are capable of doing and they find a job and can work at it for a period to see whether they can cope with it, they are given this health card for 12 months, means test-free .

An incentive allowance is paid to people in sheltered employment. It has been increased to $10 a week. That again is means test-free. There is a $10 a week non-taxable mobility allowance, which has been lauded by all the groups of handicapped people. It is for the severely handicapped who are unable to use public transport, if they are in employment or undertaking vocational training. There is also a $12 a month increase in the rate of the handicapped children's allowance, an increase which brings the allowance to $85 a month. Again, we have considerable expenditure by the Government in regional services- $750,000 to extend and improve these services under the Commonwealth rehabilitation services . We have $37m for capital facilities for handicapped persons assistance over a two-year period-$18.5m this year. Yet we are told by Senator Ryan that we have been stingy. Indeed, Senator Ryan hinted that the unemployed would abuse the system. I think that she does a grave disservice to the unemployed by saying that. I am sure that the majority of the people who are unemployed would not abuse the system by living in de facto relationships but would accept the situation as it is.

Perhaps I may mention a few of the associations that have written letters congratulating the Government on the Budget. I believe that the fact that we have not yet debated this Budget, so long after it was brought down, has blurred the situation. The Australian Council on the Ageing said:
. . . there are many welcome initiatives and we take the opportunity to express our appreciation to you and the Government.
The Council goes on in some detail. The Church of England Homes for Elderly People said:

This is just a short note to say thank you for your efforts on behalf of elderly people generally as reflected in the recent Budget, and to specifically thank you for the 50 per cent increase in the Personal Care Subsidy.
The Voluntary Care Association of Victoria, at its meeting, also asked for the Minister to be thanked. The New South Wales Council on the Ageing said:
We would like to congratulate you for what we consider to be an excellent budget for the aged.
The Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled said:
I am sure that most ACROD members would want me to write to you expressing their appreciation for the many new initiatives introduced in the current budget to assist people with disabilities.
In its media release the headline says:
Budget welcomed by disabled lobbies.
The Australian Quadriplegic Association said much the same thing:
The Association applauds the measures introduced in the Federal Budget to assist disabled people.
Interagency said:
Ryde-Hunters Hill Interagency wishes to thank you for responding to our submission for increased funding for Family Day Care.
So it goes on.

Senator Ryan's speech really does not present the situation at all. In the social welfare area the Budget has done a tremendous amount for families, not only disadvantaged families but also single income families. It has made it possible for the single income earner to keep his family together. I believe it has partially righted some of the injustices which previously existed in the taxation area. I should like to refer to that aspect again. If we compare the single income and the dual income families as a family unit, and if we take the income of the dual income families together, we find that before 1 November the single income family earning $18,000 per year paid taxation amounting to $3,602. After 1 November, it will pay $2,991. The family on a dual income of $18,000 per year prior to 1 November paid taxation amounting to $3,075. After 1 November it will pay $2,643. This indicates that the single income family has gained an amount of nearly $200. I believe that the Government will be going further in this dependent spouse rebate area, which is the area that is liable to equal up this discrepancy. I should like to congratulate the Minister and the Government on bringing in this particular taxation measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this omnibus Bill, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1982, is to put into effect the social security provisions that were foreshadowed by this Government in the 1982 -83 Budget. The amendments affect the Aged or Disabled Persons Home Act 1954, the Delivered Meals Subsidy Act 1970 and the Social Security Act 1947. Among other things they increase unemployment and sickness benefits for some people, extend eligibility for widows pensions to widows living overseas, raise rent and meal allowances, increase the personal care subsidy for people in certain institutions and provide an incentive allowance to certain invalid pensioners.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question that this Bill is a step, albeit a small and somewhat limited one, in the right direction. As the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney) indicated in his second reading speech, it recognises the plight of pensioners living in private rental accommodation, caught up, as they of course are, in the cost spiral which is due to increased interest rates, a fact which inevitably affects the rental market and hence the amount of rent that people, whether they are pensioners or not, have to pay in the private rental market. It recognises too, to a certain extent, the increasing financial problems faced by the young unemployed school leavers not all of whom, I remind Senator Walters, have parents who want or are able to care for them, despite what may well be seen as their moral responsibility. The 'generous income test'- a term used in the Minister's second reading speech-is, I suggest, more illusory than real. Certainly, while the percentage increases appear high, the actual increases mean very little. The Minister, in his second reading speech, points out that everyone who receives unemployment or sickness benefits will be able to have $10 a week of private income without affecting their rate of benefit at all , the current amount allowed being $3 a week for single people under 18 years of age and $6 a week for everyone else. I suggest that $10 a week is roughly two and a half hours cleaning, lawn mowing or window washing, and is hardly a massive amount of work to be undertaken or money earned by somebody who is trying to get himself or herself above the poverty line.

It is not my intention to go once again over the statistics relating to disadvantaged people in society. This is partly because they have been given in detail before in previous speeches, both by me and by other honourable senators, and partly because they are only ever at best an approximation, since they only ever reveal the identifiable individuals concerned and must of necessity ignore those people such as the many unemployed women, for instance, who are unable to be classified as seeking employment, perhaps because of factors such as their husband's income or because, as a previous speaker indicated, they are not specifically seeking employment since they are tied to the home as a supporting parent. Nevertheless, they are still disadvantaged people, perhaps hidden in some way from unemployment statistics. There are also those people who, out of a sense of pride, misplaced or otherwise, prefer not to register for unemployment benefit, attempting instead to go it alone. Also, as we have discovered in recent days, even the Government appears to be unable to come up with accurate figures relating to the number of unemployed in Australia.

In acknowledging that the Government has gone some way towards recognising and acting to correct a number of problem areas in the social welfare system, I must add that there are still areas which need attention. These are areas which do not necessarily require additional funds but, more appropriately, a more flexible attitude to the needs of the individuals involved. Some of these areas have been mentioned to us on a number of occasions, as Senator Walters would be aware, by people who have been appearing before the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, an area which I do not intend to go into at the moment. Let us consider, for example, the subsidy to help organisations providing accommodation for elderly people to meet the cost of employing staff to provide additional services for frail aged residents. The point I am making here is not that the Government should not be increasing personal care subsidies but that it should be putting a lot more effort into planning and co-ordinating services which will enable those who are not frail aged to stay in their own homes. At the moment people who do not necessarily need intensive nursing are taking up places in some institutions because there are simply not enough or adequate community support services to enable them to remain in their own homes. For this reason, therefore, I applaud the increased meals subsidy which was another amendment in this piece of legislation. I hope that there are additional initiatives that the Government is prepared to look at in the future which will encourage the independence of the aged in our community.

A somewhat less actual or obvious benefit however, I suspect, is the series of measures that the Government has introduced that it maintains will be of special assistance to disabled people who are in the work force or who want to work. This includes, I might add, the mobility allowance. One wonders in this economic climate, with unemployment, redundancies, retrenchments and so on at the level that they are, how many disabled people will be able to join the work force and hence benefit from the measure which I acknowledge is good in its intention but may not prove to be the value that the Government clearly hopes it will be.

My other concern, and it is the subject of the amendment that has been circulated by me, relates to certain requirements which, to my mind at least, act as a disincentive to the unemployed to improve their situation and to make themselves more eligible for employment. I refer in particular here to the limit of eight hours training which is able to be undertaken per week by a person on unemployment benefit and to the fact that a person electing to strike out on his or her own runs into the very real risk of losing the unemployment benefit, notwithstanding the fact that that person is not yet in receipt of an income. Some honourable senators may recall that I raised that latter problem some weeks ago after two South Australian men pooled their limited resources to buy a truck in order to give them mobility, particularly in the metropolitan area of Adelaide, as they went from house to house looking for work on their own initiative. Unfortunately, as a result of that their unemployment benefit was cut off and it was only after a media campaign that it was resumed. The former matter raises the question of where one draws the line. The unemployment benefit is available to anyone looking for work more or less on a full time basis. The existing legislation concedes that some people undertake training or retraining programs but it limits the time spent on these to less than two hours a day.

I remind the Senate that the unemployment benefit was originally designed to tide people over short term periods of being out of work. Unfortunately, over the last decade or so times have changed and many people are now forced to exist on the unemployment benefit for considerable periods. Compared with pensioners, for example, unemployment beneficiaries are disadvantaged in many ways, as the Labor Party amendment indicates. The fact that they are limited in the amount of training that they can undertake in any given week is yet another problem that they face. I think irrespective of whether we use the figures that the Government gave us in the Budget or the more recent figures, we would all recognise that the present level of unemployment is chronic and is a structural problem in our economic system. Now, instead of unemployed people being between jobs, many are out of the work force for months at a time. The longer they are out of the work force the less employable they become, the more depressed they become and the more need they have to attend some sort of training or retraining program. It is imperative that the Government assist those people who still have the energy and the inclination to climb out of that predicament. It is for that reason that, whilst supporting the Australian Labor Party's amendment which consists of a series of motherhood statements, I wish to add two additional points. I now move:
After sub-paragraph (iv) of the words to be added, add:
'(v) unemployed people to undertake training courses for up to 16 hours per week (instead of the present limit of 8 hours per week) before becoming ineligible for unemployment benefits, and

(vi) unemployed people to receive unemployment benefits while they are engaged in setting up a small business with the purpose of becoming self-employed but before they derive an income from that business'.

In conclusion, I repeat that it is imperative, given the changing circumstances, that governments' attitudes to pensions, to people on the unemployment benefit, to the disabled and to care of the aged in the community become more flexible than they have been in the past to allow the maximum amount of independence for those people and the minimum amount of institutionalisation and despondency in those who are becoming part of an increasingly disadvantaged proportion of our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Budget was introduced in August it contained certain social security measures. At first blush the Budget seemed to have some element of generosity for social security beneficiaries but, although it was conceived as an election Budget, this apparent generosity to social security recipients was soon seen to be quite transparent. Because the Budget was designed as an early election Budget it did contain some advances and some improvements, but after seven years of neglect what was offered could be described as too little and too late. The Opposition, through my colleague Senator Ryan, moved an amendment which I reiterate. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(a) deplores the Government's failure to protect the value of social security pensions, benefits and payments generally; and
(b) is of the opinion that the Bill should also provide for-
(i) greater increases in payments to the under-18 unemployed,
(ii) increases in payments for children to maintain the real value of those payments,
(iii) eligibility for mobility allowance for disabled persons working 18 hours a week, and
(iv) an end to the discrimination against the unemployed'.

To that Senator Haines moved a further amendment. I want to speak to the amendment moved by Senator Ryan. I intend to work through parts of the amendment , showing why it should be accepted by the Senate. The failure to protect the real value of social security pensions, benefits and payments generally will be evident from my remarks throughout my speech. I turn first to that part of the amendment which deals with discrimination against the unemployed. In doing so I shall first mention some aspects in relation to pensions. The increase in pensions payable from November, next month, is based on consumer price index increases for the six months from January to June 1982. Therefore, the increases are catch-up increases only. They are five months late at that. As Senator Ryan pointed out in her speech, they will soon be swallowed up anyway by increased charges, including the increases in sales taxes brought in in this Budget. The pension increases will take the single rate to $77.25 a week and the married rate to $128.80 a week. Despite indexation, however, the standard rate pension has fallen in terms of percentage of average weekly earnings. In 1975 the standard rate pension was about 24.4 per cent of average weekly earnings. Now it is only about 22.7 per cent.

It seems to me that we may be headed towards a situation similar to that which prevailed under the McMahon Liberal Government when the standard rate of pension was under 20 per cent of average weekly earnings. I sometimes wonder whether it will require again the advent of a Labor government to bring pensions to a reasonable level once more. The Whitlam Labor Government did just that, despite economic difficulties and frustration caused by vindictive behaviour, especially in this chamber. It raised the standard rate of pension from under 20 per cent to 24.5 per cent of average weekly earnings. We did not quite reach our goal of 25 per cent but we got close. That contrasts with a slow and gradual erosion under the Fraser Government.

Before illustrating the discrimination against the unemployed that is mentioned in the amendment, I make reference to supplementary assistance. As a consequence of this Budget the most needy of pensioners in private rental accommodation will receive supplementary assistance of up to $10 a week. But what is the position now with the unemployed? Let us first consider a breadwinner with a dependent spouse and children. Firstly, the allowance received for children is subject to tax. That is not the case for pensioners. I ask: Why do we have discrimination in such a mean way simply because a person dares to lose his or her job? The breadwinner to whom I refer cannot receive supplementary assistance. Why this discrimination? Are all the unemployed supposed to be in low cost housing so that they do not need supplementary assistance? Apart from the health care card, the unemployed do not receive fringe benefits which provide concessions in relation to public transport, rates, car registration and telephone rentals. Nor do they receive pharmaceuticals free of charge as do pensioners. Why are the unemployed regarded as less worthy in this regard than pensioners? These are areas of discrimination which could be removed by this Government but sadly they are not mentioned in the legislation before us.

So far I have considered only married persons who are unemployed. But let us look at the single unemployed people without dependants. From next month, these people will receive $12.85 a week less than the single rate pension. The unemployment benefit is not indexed. So, when the rates of pensions are adjusted next May in accordance with the indexation guidelines, the single unemployed will fall even further behind. But the discrimination does not end there. Whereas the single rate pensioner from next month will be able to earn $30 a week before his or her pension starts to cut out, the unemployed can earn only $ 10 a week. Why are not conditions similar for all benefits? Why are not conditions for unemployed persons and other pensioners as similar as possible? Surely the needs of pensioners and unemployment beneficiaries are not all that different that unemployment beneficiaries should be subject to such discrimination.

The amendment moved by Senator Ryan mentions that this Bill should provide for greater increases in payments to the under-18 unemployed. Let us look at the plight of this group. The unemployed near adults of 16 or 17 years of age have for years and years been eligible for only $36 a week. Now there is to be a paltry increase of only $4 a week-the first increase in seven years. How are young people expected to live on $40 a week? We should consider those 16 and 17- year-olds in rural areas who are forced to move to the cities in search of work. Many young people who grow up in rural areas know in their heart of hearts that they will never gain employment and that they will have to move away from home to the cities or provincial cities to search for work. Of course, these young people do not qualify for rental assistance when they do move away from home. It seems to me that this is an area about which the National Party should be particularly concerned. The National Party says that it looks after people in country areas. Even though the word 'Country' has been dropped from the name of the party, if it cares about country people it should be concerned about these young people who have to move away from their home in rural areas in search of work and have to exist, as from next month, on $40 a week with no chance of receiving supplementary assistance. This group has been the most harshly treated in this Government's seven years of neglect. I can see no reason why any honourable senator should vote against that part of Senator Ryan's amendment which seeks greater increases in payments to the under-18 unemployed.
I recently read the 11 October 1982 issue of the Christian Science Monitor. An article in that publication entitled 'Unemployment shadows darken' commenced in this way:
'And what are you going to do when you leave school?' parliamentary candidate Harriet Harmon asked a 16-year-old boy in his final year in blue-collar Peckham, South London, the other day.
'I'm going to be unemployed,' the boy said sadly.

This is only too true even in Australia for many of the people who come out of school nowadays. If this incident happened in Australia, the young lad may have said: 'I'm going to be unemployed and see how I can live on $40 a week.'

It is only too easy for us in this chamber and for those in Parliament in general to pretend that there is no real problem in respect of the young unemployed. Yet problems do exist. An article in the Courier-Mail of 21 August 1982 reported that 42 per cent of all admissions at Salvation Army hostels for men and women in Brisbane are aged 18 years or under. In other words, almost half of those people who go along to the Salvation Army hostels in Brisbane are 18 years of age or under. I would like to quote further from that Courier-Mail article. It said this as well:

One third of those who stay at the St Vincent de Paul shelter for homeless men are under 25 and one sixth are under 18. Ten years ago, the average age of those living at the society's shelters was 48. Today it is 32.

Officials of both the Salvation Army and the Society of St Vincent de Paul believe that the major cause of this increase is an inability by young people to exist on unemployment benefits, which until this week's Budget had remained at $ 36 a week since 1975.
I commend to honourable senators a reading of that article in full in the Courier-Mail. However, I want to quote some further excerpts.
A young journalist from the Courier-Mail went to the trouble of trying to live on $36 a week. This is part of what he said after his experience:

. . . 'as one who for some years has been used to earning a living wage, I found it impossible to exist without charity. My budget was just over $5 a day. Clearly I could not afford to rent a place or eat on that; the alternatives were shelters or the streets.
'Despite the knowledge that mine was only a sojourn among the unemployed, I had to make a more serious mental adjustment in order to deal with the psychological aspects of life on the dole.

'Depression was something I confronted. Faced with so much desperation, I became desperate myself. How was I going to get through my time? On occasions, it seemed a little like a gaol sentence. And on a practical level, what to do during the day?

'Unemployment, I found, is about loneliness and boredom. On $5 a day you cannot go to the pictures or the pub. Many youngsters, however, can stretch their dole cheque to include a tube of aeroplane glue.

'Unemployment is also about intellectual and emotional poverty. The 15-year-old who runs away from home and school and ends up in a hostel full of derelict alcoholics is starting life with little going for him. Virtually all his relationships are confined to the limits of his immediate environment.

One aspect of that article struck me in particular. The total article is well worth reading. I probably did not realise-and many of us probably do not realise -that if one has only $5 a day so much in life is just not available. The reporter mentioned that one cannot even go to the pictures; one cannot get away from the boredom and the desperation that one faces; one has to rely on charity for a place to live at night and a place to eat.

It may be asked why I have concentrated my remarks on the unemployed. I have done so simply because this Government, without any apparent concern, has allowed half a million Australians to become unemployed. While it has become harder and harder to obtain work, the amount that is available to the jobless by way of the unemployment benefit has become in real terms less and less. This is exactly the reverse of what the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, argued some years ago . I would like to quote from a Press statement that Mr Fraser issued back on 8 September 1974 when he was the shadow Minister for Labour. In that Press statement he talked about unemployment statistics which had been released for August 1974. He said:

. . . the government should consider closely the situation that as unemployment rises so too should unemployment benefits increase. This proposal rests on the principle that as it becomes harder to get work so too should the compensation for those out of work be increased.

The Prime Minister was saying then as shadow Minister for Labour that because unemployment was increasing in the community the unemployment benefit should increase also. At that stage the number of unemployed was about 150,000. We now have slightly over half a million people who are unemployed. Unemployment has certainly increased. I wonder what the Prime Minister now thinks about his statement that the unemployment benefit should be increased. Perhaps he has changed his mind. Perhaps he changed his mind on 11 November 1975. Before leaving the area of unemployment benefit I note that this area of the Budget was deliberately deceptive. This has been admitted by some Government members. The Budget was based on an estimated expenditure on unemployment benefit of $1,567m in 1982-83. This was based on an average of 395,000 beneficiaries for the whole year. However, in August the figure for unemployment beneficiaries was already 422,000 and climbing. No doubt the Government thought there would be an early election and that this deception would not be noticed.

The amendment moved by Senator Ryan mentions that increases are needed in payments for children for those payments to maintain their real value. I can well remember being present in this chamber when a Bill came before it which sought to replace the old child endowment scheme with a system of family allowances. I had not been a member of the Senate for very long. I can remember the surprise on this side when such an advance came from the other side. The change cost the Government nothing. We did not argue about that because it just took money from one area and put it into what we thought was a more worthy area. The system removed the income tax deductions for dependent children and used the money thus saved for the family allowance program. Unfortunately, the family allowance payments have not been properly adjusted and have thus lost much of their purchasing power. Finally, I want to outline what the publication 'Comet' said about the Budget as it relates to pensioners. The 'Comet' is a pensioners' publication which emanates from Brisbane. The publication mentioned the following: Increases in ' free area' limits-the first time since the income test was introduced in 1976; increases in fringe benefit levels, which are still far behind the levels that would prevail if full indexation had taken place; increases in supplementary assistance-the 'Comet' suggested there was a good argument for doubling the rate of assistance; and a pensioner tax rebate. The 'Comet' then went on to say that there was nothing there for the basic pensioner. Except for the small increases in supplementary assistance, I agree with the comments of that publication. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak in support of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and to commend the Government on its sensitivity to problems faced by some sections of the Australian community. I feel that the Government has put its money where its mouth is and provided substantial assistance to those in our community most in need of particular help ; namely, families with three or more children, pensioners and the unemployed. This legislation helps to consolidate those initiatives taken by the Government in last year's Budget to direct available increases in welfare expenditure to those in greatest need, doing so at a time of deepening economic recession worldwide. There is no doubt that there are some needy sections of the community which it is the Government's responsibility to try to aid. Without letting the social security bill get completely out of hand, I feel that our Government is trying to achieve just that. The 1982-83 Budget provided for an increase in the social security and welfare expenditure of the Department of Social Security from $9,997m in 1981-82 to $11,471m, which is an increase of some 18 per cent. In these difficult economic times it is certainly gratifying to see that ours is a caring government and is trying to the best of its ability, with limited funds , to relieve some of that burden within the confines of sensible economic management.

SPEECH.PARA: For those in the unfortunate position of being unemployed this Government has provided some relief. The unemployment benefit for single people aged 18 years and over who have no dependants has been increased, by $6.30 a week, to $64.40 a week, or half the unemployment benefit received by a married person. If one takes into account the automatic increases, linked to the consumer price index, that will come into effect next month, the rate will be $77.25 for a single person over 18 and $128.80 for a married couple. In addition, to encourage unemployed people to take advantage of opportunities to earn extra income and gain job experience by way of casual work, the Government will allow an unemployed person to earn more without losing his or her entitlement to unemployment benefit.

I still maintain that much could be achieved in our community if unemployed people were required to do some sort of community work in return for their unemployment cheque. There are always plenty of community-type projects that could be undertaken. I am sure that this would have the effect, firstly, of relieving the boredom of the unemployed person and, secondly, of achieving worthwhile undertakings in the community.

The income test for unemployment and sickness benefits has been made more generous for those whose income at present is largely restricted to those benefits. It will mean that everyone who receives an unemployment or sickness benefit will be able to have a private income of $10 a week without that benefit being affected adversely. The amount currently allowed is $3 a week for single people under 18 and $6 for everyone else.

Honourable senators would agree that these measures are certainly a very worthy attempt on the part of our Government to help those in our community who are most in need of assistance. I am particularly gratified that the Federal Government has seen fit to introduce some much needed relief measures for families.

Since my entry into Federal Parliament last year I have constantly stressed the need to introduce some sort of financial assistance for our Australian families. The rate of family allowance has been increased by 50 per cent for the first and second children of a family. This brings the family allowance for the first child to $22.80 a month and for the second to $32.55 a month. These measures which will cost some $375m in a full year, consolidate the increases for the third and subsequent children that were introduced in last year's Budget. Whilst it will be of particular benefit to the 1.6 million families in Australia who have one or two children, all 2.1 million families with children will benefit.

However, I feel it is worth noting that the rates are still only approximately 80 per cent of what they would have been had family allowances been indexed in the same way as have pensions. The family income supplement represents a commendable move in aiding low income families, particularly when the allowance is based on the joint income of both parents. Those people with an income less than the threshold amount will be eligible for the maximum rate of allowance for each child. The threshold amount is that income which a married couple with no children may have before they cease to be eligible for a health care card.

I also support the principle of requiring applicants for supporting parent benefit to show that they have taken appropriate steps to obtain maintenance. In the majority of cases this burden will fall on a woman finding it difficult to manage. I believe that the policy should be exercised with considerable compassion. Perhaps the Government could consider allowing the person claiming maintenance to assign his or her rights to a specialised agency set up for this purpose. The liable parent contribution scheme which applies in New Zealand may be worthy of some consideration in this regard. The increase in the spouse rebate for spouses with dependent children, combined with the lowering of the tax rate and the higher tax threshold, has improved the position of single income families to the tune of $163.50 per annum.

However, whilst this is an improvement, there is still some distance to go. I am sure that an increase in the spouse rebate would be a necessary part of this. To my way of thinking, confining the increase in the spouse rebate to the notion of dependency is a somewhat unfair and unsatisfactory concept. Even taking into consideration the good news in the Budget, the position remains that single income families are taxed more than are dual income families. This is a matter of injustice which should be remedied. Why is it that a single income family pays in tax $6.70 a week more than does a dual income family? The spouse rebate has always been available on the basis that two cannot live as cheaply as one and that an earning spouse supporting a non-earning spouse is entitled to a rebate from income.

The spouse rebate is the only acknowledgment by the Government of the myriad of services by way of which single income families, either with or without children , subsidise the commercial economy. Attaching the increase in the rebate to the notion of caring for children is an exclusive concept. It excludes spouses who may be caring for grandchildren, parents or other persons. Earlier this year the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) acknowledged the heavy reliance that State governments now place on voluntary agencies. The $830 spouse rebate allowed to those without children would not pay three weeks salary for one social worker to perform some of the duties carried out by these women. Those families that receive higher business or professional incomes already have opportunities to split their incomes. Therefore, the failure to increase fully the spouse rebate mostly affects low and middle income earners. I feel that what I have put is a worthwhile proposal and I hope that the Minister and his Department will give it serious consideration in the future.

Most pensioners will benefit from the automatic CPI-linked increases in the rates of pensions that will come into effect next month. This will increase the single rate of pension by $3.10 to $77.25 a week and the married rate by $5.20 to $128.80 a week. I also welcome the fact that from November single pensioners will be able to receive $30 of private income a week and couples $50 a week before their pension is affected. This is the first adjustment of these income levels for several years and will increase them from their current levels of $20 a week for single people and $34.50 for couples. As a result of these changes, pensioners will have an increased disposable income. They will be further assisted by the new pensioner tax rebate scheme, which is being introduced to protect pensioners with a modest income.

Other initiatives to be commended in this package include: An increase in the pensioner health benefit income limits to $54 a week for single pensioners and $ 90 a week for married pensioners; pharmaceutical concessions for all pensioners; an increase in the personal care subsidy for frail aged residents in subsidised hostels from $20 to $30 a week; a new income test-free rehabilitation allowance for pensioners or beneficiaries who undertake rehabilitation programs; an increase in the handicapped child's allowance by $12 to $85 a month; the earmarking of $300,000 for interim assistance to homeless youth; and increases in subsidy funds for services for aged and disabled people.

I applaud all these initiatives, which have been designed to assist those in our community who are in the greatest need. This Government has shown its care and compassion for the less fortunate in our country. At a time of world-wide economic recession it has acted on that concern. Within the confines of tight economic management the Federal Government has certainly put its money where its mouth is. I commend Minister Chaney and his Department for their obvious compassion and understanding of the hardships faced by some in our country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Walters for their support of the legislation and for the comments they made on the Budget provisions for welfare. The Budget provisions represent an attempt by the Government to come to grips with the difficulties which some people in Australia, indeed a great number of people, face. I think that the summary of the provisions which was made both by Senator Walters and Senator Bjelke-Petersen helps bring out the very positive nature of the social security aspects of the Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to pick up a couple of points that Senator Bjelke-Petersen made and about which she expressed some concern. She referred to the decision to reactivate the existing requirement that women seeking support of my Department who are supporting parents should have to seek maintenance. She was concerned that that decision should be administered in a humane way. I would like to assure the Senate that the rules which have been laid down governing the application of that section are that, first, the requirement is not a pre- condition to the grant of benefit. In other words, somebody seeking assistance will not be required to meet that condition before assistance will be provided. Instead, a 3-month period is allowed for the applicant to take whatever action would be reasonable to seek maintenance from the non-supporting spouse. In some cases that action would be nil. In other cases action, such as going to the courts and so on, would be required. It is intended that this rule should be administered in a flexible and humane way. I would be anxious to hear of any situations in which that was not the case.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen also raised the possibility that we could take a different approach to the whole question of maintenance by the non-supporting parent. I would like to confirm to the Senate that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and I have under consideration the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act which raised that possibility. We are examining the possibility of having a collection agency. There is already a precedent for that in Australia. In Western Australia the Family Court acts as an agent in this regard. In South Australia, the Department for Community Welfare Services acts in that regard. I think it is generally accepted among those who are informed in this area that those experiments have been worth while and warrant the same system being available around Australia. I am not anxious and my Department is not anxious for the Department of Social Security to assume that role. It is accepted that there should be some reform and change in this area.

I note also the suggestion relating to the New Zealand scheme. I do not know whether it is the New Zealand origins of the honourable senator's spouse which have led her to know of this but, in fact, the welfare Ministers of Australia have been keeping under examination the New Zealand experiment in that area. There have been early administrative problems but again it represents a most interesting approach-the imposition of a departmental administration which exacts from a non-supporting spouse a statutorily determined level of assistance or maintenance. That is something which may well be worth while implementing in Australia. We are watching the New Zealand experiment with interest. I might also add that there are similar schemes in some parts of the United States. My attention was drawn when I was in Queensland to a similar experiment in the State of New York which apparently has been quite successful. I can say to the Senate that that area of country is under careful survey.

The question of splitting incomes-that is the second matter raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen-is a matter of concern. She drew attention to the fact that, notwithstanding the concession which is given to the single income family through the dependent spouse allowance, there is still a discrepancy in favour of those who can split their income. Senator Bjelke-Petersen set the figure at $ 6.70 a week and I think that is an accurate figure. I do not produce it as an official government figure but my recollection is that the differential is of that order. In other words, there is something like a $1,300 tax advantage in splitting ones' income because one gets the benefit of two tax-free areas. That $1,300 advantage is reduced to a $300 a year advantage or something a little more than that by the $1,000 plus which is going through the dependent spouse tax rebate. The only qualification I would place on the points made by Senator Bjelke-Peterson is that it is argued by those who obtain two incomes in the family that usually costs are involved in two people earning an income. There are usually fares and other additional costs. There may be costs for additional clothing and so on. Some would argue that already the dependent spouse tax rebate does in fact more than equalise the position. It would be difficult to be exact because, of course, the expenses of earning income vary from person to person. It probably would be reasonable to say that most people who have to use public transport to go to work in Australia today would spend at least $1 a day on fares. Those offsetting matters need to be taken into account.

I should like to deal now with the less friendly part of the debate which took place this afternoon. One of the marked features of the debate was the lack of analysis by the Opposition of what was causing difficulty in the welfare area, although I concede that Senator Colston made reference to increased unemployment as a critical factor. I accept that point very readily. But what was even more marked was the total lack of any prescription by the Opposition. I did not hear any suggestion by the Opposition of what it believes it could or would do if it were in government today. Whilst I have every sympathy for the Opposition's wish not to commit itself-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I wish simply to underline a few features of that. As was pointed out in the Budget statement I put down, some 75 per cent of that very considerable expenditure increase is accounted for by increases in benefits through indexation and increases in numbers of beneficiaries. I think it is important to make that point because there is very considerable automatic growth in social security expenditure, which affects the ability of government to pick up new initiatives. I believe one should try to make it very clear that three-quarters of that very large amount of increase in welfare expenditure was picked up by those two simple things: An updating of the amount of benefits to take inflation into account and an increase in the number of beneficiaries. Of course, that still leaves 25 per cent of that very considerable sum to provide for new initiatives.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be noted that in this legislation provision is made for two new initiatives of very considerable welfare significance. I will touch on them. The first is the family income supplement, which was criticised in the debate as being too narrow but which represents the new step for Australian welfare of providing an income supplement to low income earning families with children. We have had in Australia the very odd situation whereby some low income earners could be better off unemployed than employed. Clearly, that is socially very undesirable. It is scarcely likely to contribute to good community attitudes or to a successfully operating community. The family income supplement, which provides a supplement per child for people who are in employment but earning low incomes, will remove that anomaly. I believe it is an important first step. We will need to monitor it very carefully. Even though its operation may be restricted to 30,000 families initially, it represents a new initiative on which it may well be productive to build. The second substantial initiative is the mobility allowance. It is described as being a very good initiative, but it is criticised in the amendment which is before us-I will come back to that-for being, again, too limited. I can only say that a measure which is estimated to advantage some 35,000 disabled people must be regarded as a very useful initial foray into this field. As I said at the time of the presentation of the Budget, it is a new move which we will monitor carefully and we will be prepared to adjust in the light of experience. I thought one particularly interesting suggestion put forward by Senator Ryan in her speech-I think it was probably one of the most positive points she made-and that her reference to the severely disabled woman who might be undertaking virtually the full care of a home and family. I think that is a very interesting additional category which might be considered. I give this public undertaking that in our monitoring of that scheme I certainly will ensure that further consideration is given to that category of severely disabled persons.

There are two other matters. They are much smaller in size at this stage, although they are of potentially great importance. In this Budget we have provided for a pilot project in attendant care. It is one of the major concerns brought forward during the International Year of Disabled Persons. I hope very shortly to be able to announce the beginnings of a pilot scheme in attendant care which will help to give us policy guidance in developments in that field. The other area of great significance to the disabled is that we have picked up the suggestion that we should do something to reduce the disincentives for disabled people to re-enter the work force. The matters which were touched on in debate-the provisions which will enable severely disabled people to get health care cover for a period of up to a year, which will enable them to get eased readmission to the ranks of invalid pensioners if their attempts to re-enter employment fail-are important steps in removing some of the very real disincentives which at present face severely handicapped people when they wish to enter open employment. I believe that this is a positive step which would be generally welcomed around the chamber.

I will turn in a moment to the amendments proposed by both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. First, I just touch on a couple of the other points of detail which were raised. Reference was made by both Senator Ryan and, I think, Senator Colston, to the level of indexed benefits and their alleged loss of value. It is, of course, by definition a fact that at present the bulk of social security income maintenance payments is protected against the ravages of inflation. They are protected against changes in the cost of living by a twice yearly automatic adjustment. That adjustment takes place without the need for further intervention by this Parliament. It is also true, of course, that if average weekly earnings rise at a rate greater than that of inflation the relative value of pensions to average weekly earnings will decline. TALK.START.PARA: —That table confirms that during the life of the Australian Labor Party the standard rate of pension reached a peak of 24.5 per cent of average weekly earnings. It is interesting to see that during the rest of 1975 that declined to 23.7 per cent. In the final quarter of 1975 it went back up to 24.4 per cent. Those variations reflect the changes in average weekly earnings when notched up against the biannual changes to pensions according to changes in the cost of living. The history since we came into government is of some interest. The percentage ran along at a fairly steady rate of between 23.9 per cent and over 24 per cent of average weekly earnings over a period of some years. It reached 24.9 per cent in the June quarter of 1977, it was 25 per cent in the June quarter of 1978 and reached 25.2 per cent in the December quarter of 1978. It is true that since that time there has been a decline. That reflects the fact that over recent years average weekly earnings have increased at a much faster rate than has the rate of inflation. That is the simple explanation. It does not represent a reduction in the purchasing power of the pension; rather, it simply represents a change in the relative position of the pension to average weekly earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: It remains true that if, in Australia in 1982, during a period when we have economic difficulties, employed Australians continue to demand increases in their earnings greater than increases in productivity pensioners, the unemployed and all other sections of the community will have to suffer by comparison. One cannot get quarts out of pint pots, as Mr Hayden said in the 1975 Budget debate. The fact is that if wage and salary earners take out of the system increases which are greater than true economic growth, by definition, there has to be less left for pensioners, for profits and for all sectors of the economy which are dependent upon taking from the total pool. So if one wishes to change the ratio of pensions and other benefits to average weekly earnings it may require increases in pensions and benefits and it certainly will require the sort of wage restraint that this Government has been seeking.

I want to touch on one other matter which is specific, and that is the very critical references which are made in these amendments to homeless youth. It seems to me that Senator Ryan, who spoke for the Opposition, had not bothered to study the report to which she referred, the report on homeless youth from the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. I refer her and the Senate to that report and in particular to page 161, which refers to government responsibility with respect to unemployed youth. The report states:

In the majority of cases the government's responsibility is to support the family, not to take over its function. The real dilemma of government is knowing at what point family support for a young person can be considered to have ceased to exist. Both parents and youth should not be enabled to readily shirk their responsibilities and obligations. At the same time, governments should not wait until the last moment to provide assistance.
At page 163 the Senate Committee report states:

In most countries examined, there appears to be a very strong attitude that families should support unemployed youth. For example, in West Germany there is a statutory requirement that families and relatives must support all children until such time as they are able to obtain full time employment.
The Committee was a Labor and Liberal committee of which, amongst others, Senator Grimes was a member. The report continued at page 164:

The Committee has framed its income recommendations around a demonstrated needs basis. Consequently, it has been unable to accept recommendations from many witnesses who have proposed across the board increases in unemployment benefits and other allowances. While across the board increases would be by far the simplest of schemes to administer, the cost to revenue would be extremely high, and the implementation of such a scheme under the present economic conditions would almost certainly mean less funds available for other social welfare programs.
I turn to the specific recommendations of the Committee. The report states:

The Committee RECOMMENDS that an allowance equivalent to the difference between the over 18 years of age unemployment rate and the junior unemployment benefit rate should be made available to certain unemployed youth under 18 years of age. These would include:
(a) those who have had to establish themselves, for one reason or another, away from the family or statutory home;

(b) those whose family's financial circumstances are such that the additional benefit would enable the family to remain together as a unit rather than the young person being forced into possible homelessness.
I will not quote at any greater length from that report.

The point I want to make is that the Committee did not recommend overall increases in unemployment benefit for that age group. Rather, it recommended a more selective approach. That report was available to me and to the Government on, I think, the day of the Budget. I had preliminary discussions with the Committee during this year, for which I thank it, and I was in part guided by its advice in what came out of the Budget. But I point out that with respect to youth we have, firstly, increased the rate of unemployment benefit, secondly, increased the rate of support to those caring for homeless youth and, thirdly, made new funds available to agencies working with homeless youth. That serious problem is one recognised as such by the Government and we are seeking to respond to it in a responsible and proper way. I believe that the measures that we put in the Budget are in accord with the spirit of the two-party recommendations of the Senate Select Committee and I undertake that we will do a close policy examination in this area in conjunction with State Ministers over the coming months.

I turn to the amendments moved by the Opposition and the Democrats. The Senate will not be surprised to know that the Government rejects the views contained in the amendments. I will touch on the various components of the Labor Party's amendment. Firstly, the amendment states that the Senate:
(a) deplores the Government's failure to protect the value of social security pensions, benefits and payments generally.

I simply remind the Senate of this Government's institution of twice-yearly indexation and of the fact that non-indexed benefits have over recent Budgets received indexation level adjustments. So there has been a protection of the purchasing power of virtually all of the pensions and benefits paid through my Department.
The next part of the amendment states that the Senate:
(b) is of the opinion that the Bill should also provide for-
(i) greater increases in payments to the under-18 unemployed.
I have already referred to the Senate Committee report and to the fact that the Government has made adjustments which I believe are consistent with that report. The amendment continues:
(ii) increases in payments for children to maintain the real value of those payments.

I suggest that the 50 per cent increase in family allowance for first and second children, and the addition to the dependent spouse rebates where dependent children are involved, represents a substantial concession to the very real needs of families with children. The amendment continues:
(iii) eligibility for mobility allowance for disabled persons working 18 hours a week.

I simply say that that represents a reduction of only two hours a week on what the Government proposes and I have indicated that we regard this as something to be monitored and watched in practice. We will be prepared to adjust in the light of experience. The final point of complaint in the Labor Party's amendment calls for:
(iv) an end to the discrimination against the unemployed.
That was mainly said to relate to the failure to index benefits. As I have just pointed out, in fact these allowances have received indexation level adjustments in the current Budget.
The amendment moved by the Australian Democrats provides:
(v) unemployed people to undertake training courses for up to 16 hours per week (instead of the present limit of 8 hours per week) before becoming ineligible for unemployment benefits.

To this proposal, I say that the eight hours limit was only ever regarded as a guide within the Department. It was put down as a figure below which benefit could automatically be permitted. The practice in the Department-I understand there has been a recent change-is to be much more flexible in that judgment. It is my wish that the Department be flexible, and that those people who are undertaking training which does not preclude their availability for fulltime work be eligible for benefits. I do not think there is any great distance between us on that point.
The final point raised by the Democrats is:

(vi) unemployed people to receive unemployment benefits while they are engaged in setting up a small business with the purpose of becoming self-employed but before they derive an income from that business.

I wish to say that, whilst we have some room to move in that area, the suggestion that people engaged in business and self-employed ought to be entitled to unemployment benefit during periods where they can claim not to have income opens up a very difficult line of country. The fact is that what income is available to a person with a business will often vary considerably from time to time, from week to week, from month to month. The determination whether a business is profitable is not always an easy matter. For example, a business is often without cash because of its expanding needs for working capital. The business may well be in a position where profits are being made, income tax liability is accruing and yet there is a real shortage of ready cash. As a practising solicitor in a well established firm, I sometimes found that there was not very much ready cash because of working capital and other requirements. There is a substantial point there but it is not an area in which the Department blindly administers the rule. Factual cases are examined carefully. But I wish to emphasise that it is an area of very considerable difficulty in which the possibility of very real abuse can be opened up if it is allowed to go too far.

The Budget represents an attempt by the Government to come to grips with some of the realities of Australia in 1982. Many of the measures contained in it reflect views which were put forcefully to me by disabled and aged persons over the past 12 months. I believe that we can properly claim that it is a reasonable contribution to Australian welfare in 1982.

I close by saying that about the time when we were preparing the Budget I was struck by the words of Mr Ronald Mendelsohn who wrote a book called Fair Go on welfare issues in Australia which is very critical in many parts of the efforts that we have made. There are two things which are worth remembering in a debate where we have naturally concentrated on the provisions of cash benefits and services by government. I quote very briefly from pages 197 and 198 of that book in which Mr Mendelsohn said:
A welfare society calls for qualities of spirit and effort, love and toleration , not necessarily present in such welfare states as we have so far seen.
I say 'Amen' to that and believe that that is an important element of having a good welfare system. On page 198, he states:
Only a society technically advanced and producing a steadily rising flow of physical things, skilled services and advanced information could really be a welfare society.
I say 'Amen' to that also. I trust that Australia will soon be able to resume a path of economic growth which is essential to the solution of the welfare problems of 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish very briefly to indicate that the Opposition is prepared to accept the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats which seeks to add sub-paragraphs (v) and (vi) to the amendment moved by the Opposition. In so doing, I reply to Senator Chaney's assertions that we have failed to offer any alternative in this debate. I point out to him that it is not the role of the Opposition, 12 months before an election is to take place , to detail in an expenditure way how we would deal with this problem of social welfare payments. We are not in the business of determining the role of government when we are in opposition; but we are in the business of raising valid criticisms of what we believe to be crumbs from the table in respect of the way in which the Government is dealing with social security benefits. We are also in the process of preparing a program which, when the election date is announced, will relate to what our policy would be at that election. Our policy at an election this year would be clearly different because of different economic circumstances from what it would be if an election were held in November or December 1983. To accept the challenge by the Minister and announce where we stand today when we might have an entirely different set of circumstances next year, to which even the Minister refers, would put us in the invidious position of the Government being able to say that we were being irresponsible when we were obviously dealing with a different set of circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the relevant question which must be faced by the Senate is that this Government's Budget for the ensuing year is based upon a no-growth concept. If the Opposition were to accept that principle, it would find itself in a difficult position as regards social security benefits. Our policies are designed to regenerate the Australian economy, to get growth and to get across to the community a development concept which would provide increases in average weekly earnings and in living standards and which would enable us then to perform a proper function of indicating at an election time what our policies would be in respect of social security pensions and unemployment benefit, particularly unemployment benefit.

Let us face the fact that in the brief couple of months since the Budget was first put together we have seen an alarming increase in the degree of unemployment. That in itself has prompted the Opposition to raise the question of the rubbery figures in respect of social security payments to the unemployed. If the rate of about 1,200 people a day losing their jobs were to continue during the balance of this year and most of 1983, what an absurd position the Opposition would be placed in if it were to telegraph what it would do in the light of a dramatic fall in revenue and a dramatic increase in social security payments.

Without rehashing the questions raised by the Opposition, it ought to be said that our proposals are designed to be critical of the Government's Budget allocations in this respect, and we reject emphatically any suggestion that in so doing we are being irresponsible and lacking in any detail about what we propose to offer as an alternative to the Budget. The Government is responsible for producing the Budget. We are responsible for criticising it. When the time comes, we shall be announcing our policies, designed to get the economy back into a healthier state and, as a consequence of that, we shall be in a position to offer very improved and increased social security benefits to all those who qualify at present.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of circumstances beyond my control, I could not mention some matters during the Committee stage. However, I should like to pose a question for the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). I shall have to pose all of it in one question because I shall not be able to break it up at this stage. My question relates to clause 108 of this legislation . Among other things, and perhaps principally, clause 108 proposes to amend section 22 (2) of the Social Services Amendment Act 1981 to ensure that the savings provision has a once only effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I pose the following question: Under the provisions that exist now, before this legislation comes into effect, if a person was in government housing on 1 February and was receiving supplementary assistance and, therefore, retained the supplementary assistance due to the savings provision, and subsequently undertook casual employment and lost the eligibility for supplementary assistance, would such a person have been eligible to receive the supplementary assistance once again after having come off that casual employment, assuming that all other conditions were equal and that the person was still in the government owned residence? If that is so, is that what clause 108 is intended to rectify? If the clause is intended to rectify something else, perhaps I could be informed of what that is. Also, why was it necessary to deem this to have taken effect from 1 February this year rather than from some date after this Bill is passed-say, when it receives royal assent, or 1 November, or something like that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply- I am glad that Senator Colston has had the opportunity on the third reading to raise the matter which he wished to raise in Committee. I would not wish to see him deprived of that opportunity because he has been following up this matter with some care for some time. Indeed, he raised it with me last August and I have just had to write him a letter correcting the reply which I gave him then. The example raised by Senator Colston in the debate this afternoon is the situation of a person who is in government housing and who would, therefore, under the provisions that came into operation on 1 February, not be eligible for supplementary assistance because he is getting subsidised government accommodation, but who continues to receive supplementary assistance because of the saving provision in the Social Services Amendment Act 1981. That person would lose that entitlement to supplementary assistance when he lost entitlement under the rules applying before 1 February 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: If, for example, a person receiving supplementary assistance in those circumstances had an increase in income, the old income test would be applied, the entitlement to supplementary assistance would disappear and would not be revived subsequently. The position is that a person in the circumstances raised by Senator Colston would not be entitled to supplementary assistance as the Act is presently drafted if it were properly applied.

The anomaly that we are seeking to rectify in the current amending Bill is the situation of a person who was receiving supplementary assistance prior to February 1982 and who qualified for a higher rate of assistance under the new provisions. It was intended that that person would cease to have his saved eligibility. If, for instance, he had a continuing entitlement, but was entitled at a higher rate under the new provisions, he would be effectively given continuity and that continuity applied even if he lost eligibility and then regained it. In other words, he could reapply if he fell under the old pre- February conditions. That is the anomaly. It arose because of the inclusion of two words which are being deleted by the clause to which Senator Colston referred, the words 'or applies' in section 22 of the principal Act. So the particular circumstance which Senator Colston has raised on the third reading is not a circumstance which is affected at all by the legislation which is currently before the Senate. What is being rectified is a quite different circumstance in which a person who was receiving supplementary assistance prior to February 1982 and who qualified for a higher rate of assistance under the new provisions was able to go back and claim under the pre-February 1982 provisions. That was an anomaly that was unintended and it will cease to be by the removal of those two words.

TALK.START.PARA: —But why deem it to come into effect as from 1 February?

—It is deemed to come into effect as from 1 February because, as far as we know, in general the legislation has been administered in that way anyway. We are simply making it apply from 1 February, which is when it was thought to apply. In the main, the provisions have been administered in that form. If any person has received additional assistance because of departmental error, there will be no claim against that person for recovery.
