TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition would like to congratualate the Government on the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill 1982 . It represents the most flattering piece of repatriation legislation to be brought down in a long time in that it mirrors so clearly key aspects of Australian Labor Party policy. What amazes me, however, is the bare-faced manner in which the Government is now touting reforms which it rejected out of hand less than 12 months ago when the Opposition had the temerity to move them here and in another place. Let me remind the Senate of some of those reforms that are now to be-properly in our view, of course-enshrined in legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody can possibly object to the proposal that extends eligibility for repatriation benefits to members of peacekeeping forces who served as representatives of Australia prior to 2 November 1981. When this Government amended the Repatriation Act a year ago to give such benefits to those serving overseas after 2 November 1981, my colleague Senator Grimes moved that repatriation benefits be extended to their predecessors. The Government rejected this. When, earlier this year, the Government moved to extend entitlement to cover Australian members of the multinational force now serving in Sinai, the Opposition again attempted to persuade the Government to rethink its dogmatic position on those who had served with peacekeeping observation and monitoring forces before 2 November 1981. The Government again rejected it. Then in July this year the ALP national conference adopted as part of its policy on veterans' affairs a commitment to introduce legislation relating to overseas service so as to provide equality of repatriation entitlements for veterans of all wars, designated campaigns or peacekeeping duties at least equivalent to those now enjoyed by World War II veterans. And surprise, surprise! The Government, sniffing the wind of an early election, decided to adopt this measure in relation to peacekeeping duties and turned it into its very own Budget promise.

The fact that the measure is baldly announced with no attempt at justification shows how much the Government thinks of the men who will benefit. There is no praise for the quiet heroism of these forgotten men; no understanding of the unreported hazards of peacekeeping operations; no apology for the years they have been kept in limbo; no listing of the places in which they served out of sight and, to all intents and purposes, out of mind. So let me remind the Government of the men we are talking about now, the men the Opposition was talking about, apparently in vain, only a year ago and again earlier this year. It is a long list. From 1947 to 1951 Australia participated in peacekeeping groups in Greece following the civil war there. Similarly, Australia was represented in the peacekeeping force in Indonesia from 1947 to 1957 following the war against the Dutch. From 1956 to the present day we have been part of the United Nations truce supervisory organisation in the Middle East. Australians have been serving since 1949 in the Kashmir in a similar role in the wake of border conflicts between India and Pakistan.

We sent a small contingent to the Lebanon in 1958 and assisted United Nations forces in the Congo between 1960 and 1964. Cyprus, of course, has been a regular posting for Australian police officers serving with the United Nations civilian police force since 1964. Australian servicemen joined the observer mission that was sent to the Yemen after United Nations intervention there in 1963-64. Again in the Middle East, our involvement in the United Nations Emergency Force II in the Suez Canal area lasted from 1973 to 1980. Australia's role in the observation operation during the 1980 Zimbabwe election was our most recent international involvement, save for the controversial Sinai contingent which commenced service this year.

I regret very much that the Royal Australian Air Force observation unit that served at Ubon in Thailand in 1962 is not part of this list for the Government's purposes, although it clearly should be. It goes without saying that we support this part of the amendment. I urge the Government to review as a matter of urgency the delineation of designated campaigns to include the RAAF contingent at Ubon and any other unit so displaced in terms of access to benefits and defence force homes, et cetera.

The notorious 'arisen out of' provision is also subject to the amendments proposed by this Bill. The Opposition supports the extension of what is commonly known as the 'arisen out of or attributable to' provision to members of the forces who participated in conflicts other than World War II. I have already mentioned the ALP platform item dealing with this. It is supported by other items promising the extension of liberal treatment to all ex-service personnel disabled as a result of war service and to their dependants. The ALP is firmly of the opinion that our ex-servicemen are entitled to know that their disabilities will be treated and that they themselves will be treated compassionately.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) made gratuitous mention of the worries of Vietnam veterans in this context. He spoke derisively of the publicity given to the veterans' belief that they have been disadvantaged by not being subject to the 'arisen out of' clause applicable to World War II veterans. He claimed that very few instances have come to attention where eligibility for disability pension would arise because of the application of the 'arisen out of or attributable to' provision apart from the 'occurrence' provision. The simple reason for this is that many veterans have assumed their probable ineligibility and have not bothered to apply. There is no doubt that their patronage of the counselling service is to some extent affected by whether they believe they will get a fair go if they do bother to lodge a claim.

A great deal of the correspondence and personal representations senators and members deal with are from veterans who, rightly or wrongly, believe they are getting a raw deal from the Department of Veterans' Affairs and its agencies. Much of it concerns what they are convinced to be actual misdiagnosis and poor treatment of conditions they believe to be due to their war service. This is particularly so with Vietnam veterans suffering classic post-traumatic stress syndrome. An unknown number of suicides is a chilling reminder of how permanent was the damage the veterans suffered. We therefore support this move by the Government, a move we have advocated before, in the name of those veterans and their families who have been denied a fair deal.

It is good at last to have it acknowledged by this Government, whose Liberal predecessors have been such enthusiastic and shameless war-mongers, that, as the Minister said: 'The Government considers that the same principles of eligibility should apply to all veterans for all conflicts . . .'. We accept in good faith the rider to that comment-'. . . unless there is good reason to introduce specific principles and provisions for particular conflicts or for particular groups of veterans'-and trust that it will not be used in any other than the best interests of our veterans.

Having said that, I remind the Government that the single move most calculated to assist the well-being and state of mind of Vietnam veterans would be, as we continually urge, to hold an independent judicial inquiry into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on Vietnam veterans. This proposal was actually passed in the Senate a year ago, only to be cynically ignored by the Government. It is now the all but unanimous policy of the National Conference of Ex-Service Organisations, although the Returned Services League, out of deference to the Government, has held the line against such a move.

Is it not strange, that this Government, which has been so anxious to appoint royal commissions and inquiries into everything under the sun, including the bottom of the harbour, just cannot face the prospect of opening the Pandora's box containing the legacy of the Vietnam war? But if it is good enough to have a royal commission into the substitution of meat carcasses, it is surely good enough to have an independent judicial inquiry into the effects of herbicides and pesticides on men prepared to die in Vietnam, many of whom, having survived that war, have made the terrible decision to end their lives here.

I turn again to the Government's promised review of the 'arisen out of' provisions which it claims will be part of the thorough review of all repatriation legislation now about to be undertaken. It is not the first review of legislation in this government's term of office. It would not be too harsh to advise veterans not to wait, breathless, for its outcome, since most previous reviews have been singularly ineffective and the slow moving and cumbersome Department has been either loathe to implement reform or, quite simply, incapable of effecting reform. As always, it is the veterans who have suffered unconscionable delays in the hearing and determination of their claims. It may be a truism, but here, more than anywhere else in the system, justice delayed is justice denied. In fact it might be more accurate to say that justice delayed is justice betrayed.

One of the further inexplicable quirks in the system is sorted out by this legislation. At last the Government, which was so tardy in introducing the category of benefit at all, is to extend service pension eligibility to Commonwealth and allied mariners who served in a theatre of war during World War II. The indefatigable battlers for these ex-merchant mariners have finally got a reward for their persistence in pursuing their particular cause, a cause supported by the ALP and denied by successive conservative governments.

When the Minister was queried last year on why the long-delayed pension was not being extended to Commonwealth and allied mariners, his lame and patently untrue rejoinder was that nobody had asked for it. That, of course, was completely untrue-just ask Bob Nelson from Newcastle or Joy Antcliffe from Perth who spearheaded the drive for recognition of the mariners' contribution. In the words of John Curtin, recalled by a merchant mariner's wife during the debate on this matter:
They wear no uniform, but just a badge with the letters MN. When you see it, raise your hat to the wearer.
At least now the remaining men who wore that badge in World War II will have a tangible reminder of the gratitude of us all.

For those veterans who received the 100 per cent general rate in respect of suffering pulmonary tuberculosis prior to November 1978, which this Government tore out of their hands at about the same time it decided to tax newsboys, there is in this legislation a belated acknowledgement of error. There is no retrospectivity, of course, because these are not tax dodgers, just veterans. But at least it is being restored and again the Opposition has seen its stand vindicated by a government which chooses to restore justice only in accord with the prevailing election winds.

Another section of ALP policy adopted by the Government is in respect of disregarding as income any disability pension when assessing levels of service pension and fringe benefits. The Minister claims that the RSL has described this move as historic. What a pity that the RSL did not so proclaim the same ALP policy adopted in July-a month before this one surfaced in the Budget.

Finally, I turn to the specific additional measures which the Opposition believes should be incorporated in this Bill. There is clearly a need for Government to recognise the selfless contribution that the wives of totally and permanently incapacitated ex-servicemen have made to the care of their husbands over the years, often to the detriment of their own health. This is a cause that has been taken up by TPI associations and the National Conference of Ex-Service Organisations, and the ALP platform on veterans' affairs now includes an undertaking to provide relief and treatment, where appropriate, for the wives of TPI veterans. I hardly need cite again the overwhelming case for the independent judicial inquiry which this Senate endorsed almost a year ago. On behalf of the Opposition, I now move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Bill should provide for-
(a) increased benefits for the wives of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans, and
(b) an immediate independent judicial inquiry into the effect on Vietnam veterans of their exposure to herbicides and pesticides.'
I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill is the second such Bill the Senate has discussed within the year. It is interesting that the legislation is undergoing change at a time of considerable turmoil amongst veterans' organisations concerning the purposes and functioning of the Repatriation Act, which affects them so closely. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) has announced that he is undertaking a complete review of the Act. The Australian Democrats would certainly support such a review, particularly if the Minister carried out the promises that he has made publicly that the ex-service associations will be intimately involved in the redrafting or reworking of the Repatriation Act. This Bill gives to veterans a range of benefits that anyone who has been working in the field would certainly believe is their wont. They would certainly thank the Government for having moved on so many measures at the one time. I believe that in a sense some of the people feel overwhelmed by the fact that with so little movement in many areas they will receive so much in a short time. They are extremely grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go through some of the items covered by the Bill because I believe that a number of the items are extremely important to certain groups of veterans. In a debate such as this it is worthwhile raising why the Government has a duty and an obligation to these veterans. Many people in the community seem to feel that bludgers may be afoot in this area. I feel it is necessary to raise the types of difficulties that many veterans run up against in acquiring these benefits. Many people think that one needs simply to write in to get these benefits. That is very far from the case.

The first matter I raise relates to the proposal in the Bill to extend the liability provision 'arisen out of or attributable to' to World War I, Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam veterans. I introduced a private member's Bill in relation to Vietnam veterans and sought an amendment to the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act. In my second reading speech I acknowledged that other veterans suffered under an identical disability and it would be necessary to amend the legislation under which they come. Certainly the amendment to the repatriation legislation is a much neater and clearer way of bringing all those veterans into the same eligibility category.

The Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his second reading speech seemed to play down somewhat the necessity for this legislative change. I feel this is unfortunate because an appeal against a decision of the Repatriation Review Tribunal lodged in the New South Wales District Registry of the Federal Court of Australia specifically questioned this item. In particular, under the heading ' Questions of law to be raised on the Appeal', the notice of appeal states:
Did the Tribunal fail to apply section 6 (1) of the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962 . . . by treating the expression 'has resulted from' as if it were 'arising out of'?

I think the point is well taken in that appeal. I believe that if that appeal had been proceeded with the veteran may very well not have succeeded, that on at least one reasonable reading of the Act as it stands those veterans were not covered to the same extent as are World War II veterans. So I think that this change is extremely important, not only for that reason in law but also because so many veterans at their conferences in the last year have looked at this aspect and have been concerned about whether it applies to them. I believe that that in itself would justify the legislative change that is proposed in the Bill before us today.

The Bill seeks to disregard the disability pension in the income test for the purpose of determining eligibility for service pension and fringe benefits. I think that this is an excellent move and again I congratulate the Government on that amendment. I believe it is something for which various organisations have fought over a long period. Those organisations are very grateful to the Government for having acceded to what I believe has been an extremely reasonable request on their part in terms of the basic philosophical reason the country supports their members for the services that they in turn have given to the country.

The legislation also seeks to extend eligibility for the service pension to former Commonwealth and allied mariners. It also seeks to extend benefits to representatives of Australia who served with peacekeeping, monitoring and observing forces. As Senator Ryan has already suggested, this is something that has been urged upon the Government for some time-certainly it was urged upon it during the last debate we had on repatriation legislation in, I believe, April this year. It is good to see that at last the logic of those claims has struck the Government with sufficient force for it to do something and to include them in this piece of legislation.

The legislation also proposes that a range of benefits be increased. Whilst I feel that this is certainly welcomed by veterans, it is certainly no more than their due. Indeed, I think it would be far better if all of these attendant allowances and pensions were indexed. I believe that we ought to remove the necessity for legislation to come before the Senate time and again to increase these amounts. The indexation of benefits would give stability to these pensions in terms of the expectations of the veterans themselves. I hope that this is the last time that the Senate has to deal with legislation which seeks to increase benefits such as the attendant allowance. Legislation should be introduced, upon review of the present arrangements, to index all benefits so that we have a settled position, not one which can be taken up at times which are politically opportune. We should bear in mind the needs of pensioners.

The Government in this legislation picks up one other item which was the subject of a private members Bill I introduced into this place. I refer to the restoration of the disability pension at the 100 per cent general rate for veterans who received or were eligible to receive a disability pension for pulmonary tuberculosis. It is interesting to note that on the last occasion we debated this matter-that was on 26 November 1981-the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, in his reply to why it was being rejected at the time by the Government , said:
For these reasons, the Government maintains its opposition to the Bill. It believes that its decision in 1978 was correct . . .

Thank goodness at last it has seen that that statement of the Minister was not correct, that its position was wrong in equity and in justice and that that ought to have been the case in 1978. Again, I believe it is a pity that, having recognised the justice of the case, those pensioners who have been deprived since 1978 and who have suffered that disability since 1978 are not now to be recompensed upon the belated recognition of the justice of their case. I am not quite sure what type of argument is being used in this case. However, the argument presumably must run as follows: From 1945 to 1978 someone suffered from the disability of pulmonary tuberculosis; from 1978 to 1983 the person did not suffer from that disease; and from 1983 onwards he did suffer from it. That is an absurd and farcical proposition if ever there were one. I believe the tuberculosis veterans themselves see as absurd and grossly unjust this situation which has been visited upon them by an arbitrary act of government and firmly upheld by governments of all political persuasions.

I believe that this measure has probably done the Government very little good in terms of creating a feeling of confidence amongst pensioners, a feeling that if they do not keep battling for the pensions and allowances that have been granted to them by government a predatory government will take those benefits away. In a sense I think that is an excessively poor situation. Many ex-service organisations have not had an influx of new members. However, veterans from our most recent conflicts have seen fit to form special organisations which are concerned with people who served in those conflicts. They have not, to a great extent, become involved in organisations such as the Totally and Permanently Disabled Soldiers Association and other organisations which were established following World War II. Therefore, many of these organisations, which still have a great deal of work on their hands, do not have young members with the physical capacity to carry out their onerous duties on behalf of their fellow veterans. I believe it is a pity that the Government should engage in an act such as this and so create in those veterans' minds the belief that of necessity they must constantly fight over and over again simply to retain those items that they felt had been sworn to them almost on oath by government after government.

I raise two other matters on the Repatriation Act in this debate since it is one of the occasions on which one can look at the Act and at what might be the more immediate problems that seem to be facing the veterans' organisations. One of those must be-I know that it is one matter to which the Minister has paid a great deal of attention but it is one to which, I feel, we cannot pay too much attention-the method by which a person can get a claim upheld. As I mentioned at the beginning, that method is a long and arduous one for many veterans. It is not simply a matter, as is often believed in the community at large, of writing a letter saying: 'I am a veteran and I want an allowance'. That is far from the case. Yet it seems to be abroad, certainly in many young people's minds, that this is the operation.

The operation is a very searching one. It is one in which a great deal of care and consideration takes place. The operation is extremely costly. The point of my concern is the possibility that we may now have created a system in which we are putting people to too great a pressure. If one looks at the number of appeals which are going through to the Repatriation Review Tribunal one will see that far too many are going through to that level. If one looks at the statistics it would seem that many more appeals ought to be being granted at the Repatriation Board level. I believe more appeals could be granted at the Board level if there were closer application to the items that appear in the Repatriation Act itself.

It is not so long ago that we saw an historical judgment of the High Court of Australia which suggested to the Repatriation Review Tribunal that it was not interpreting the law as it was clearly laid down in the Repatriation Act. I believe that the Repatriation Act in many ways contains some extremely useful commonsense notions that are being put aside in favour of more legalistic approaches. While these more legalistic approaches are providing many of the ranges of appeal for veterans, they also seem to be providing them with a great deal more heartache, worry, concern and, above all, cost. This is an area which I believe must be on the top of the priority list of any review that is undertaken. On looking at the more commonsense notions which are currently available, while not taking away those rights of appeal, I believe more appeals could be granted at the Board level and fewer would have to go on to appeal. If one reads some of the reasons for decisions which are stated at the top levels, one will find it almost incomprehensible why claims had not been granted prior to the case that I mentioned.

The other item I raise concerns the notion of eligible service which has been raised with the Minister in recent times. I hope that in the Minister's reply he will point to what is the current activity and the thinking of the Government in relation to those items. I refer to the principal Act and sections 107H, 107J and 107K which, when taken together, interpret what is meant by eligible service , the problem being that in terms of the Act a disabled regular serviceman or servicewoman, or retired regular serviceman or servicewoman, will have some difficulty in what seems to be an emerging interpretation-I put it as low as that-on the part of the Repatriation Boards in relation to what might be eligible service. I believe that it should not be necessary to have these interpretations climb to the level of the High Court. The costs, such as those involved in the previous case which was taken to that extent, have almost always come down on behalf of the Repatriation Act's more commonsense approach. If one looked at the Act and at the interpretation and tenor of that Act one would not accept that emerging interpretation of the Repatriation Board. Rather one would come down on behalf of the veterans and take the widest possible interpretation of what might be eligible service. Since the Minister has had some prior notification in relation to that matter, it might be as well to leave that side of it to enable us to complete this stage of the legislation today. At the Committee stage of the Bill, I will be moving two amendments. I think that it is appropriate to leave the discussion of those amendments until that stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Opposition senators and the Australian Democrats for their support of the legislation. Before dealing with some of the real benefits of this legislation, I wish to deal with a few points that have been raised in the course of the debate. Firstly, I turn to some of the comments made by Senator Ryan. In the first place, she drew attention to the fact that in her estimation the Government had somehow purloined the Australian Labor Party's policy in respect of veterans' affairs and had adopted that policy almost holus-bolus in this legislation. I deny that. Until I read a copy of the Australian Labor Party's conference statement of policy which was incorporated in the House of Representatives Hansard on 13 October 1982 by Dr Blewett, we had no access at all to this information. As far as I know, there has been no published document available to the general public in respect of policy statements of the ALP. I note that this veterans' affairs policy was apparently resolved at the biennial conference of the Australian Labor Party in Canberra held between 5 and 9 July this year. Anybody who understands the Budget processes of government would know that the process by which new policy proposals are put into the decision making process within government starts back in February of any year. Consequently, I can assure the Senate that I had no knowledge of what the ALP's policy would have been at the time when I determined certain policy initiatives which were subsequently decided upon by the Government during its Budget deliberations.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from the attempt by Labor to take credit where none was due, let me just make one or two other points that Senator Ryan made during her speech. She drew attention to the fact that there were still considerable problems with delays in the determination of appeals and claims put forward by veterans. That is so. There is considerable difficulty in this area. That has been acknowledged by the Government on many occasions. However, steps have been taken to try to improve that situation. I think that Senator Macklin drew our attention to one of the very considerable reasons why this does occur. In fact the system has over time become more legalistic than it was intended to be and that is as a result of successive representations by the ex-service community and the findings of the Toose inquiry, which led to a series of amendments being made to the law in 1977, and consequently led to a far more complex and more legalistic form of legislation and determination system than perhaps there ought to be in situations especially of the kind to which Senator Macklin drew our attention.

This area does deserve a considerable rethink. The Government, in concert with the ex-service organisations, is undertaking a review at this very moment. A number of suggestions have been put forward and discussed at various meetings of veterans' organisations. I will not deal with those matters in detail at this stage but they could result in very significant changes in the extent of the delay experienced under the present system.

Senator Ryan raised the matter of airmen who had served at Ubon in Thailand. Last year I undertook to look into that matter and it remains under consideration. It is one of those that I will be reviewing within the context of the overall review of the legislation that I announced a month or two ago. Senator Macklin drew our attention to the position of tuberculosis pensioners and the restoration of the 100 per cent pension rate payable to those who were otherwise entitled to it before its withdrawal in 1978. He quoted me as saying that the 1978 decision was correct. It was based on medical evidence available at the time that those who were receiving TB pensions had been in every case, I believe, cured as a result of treatment received through the repatriation system or otherwise. Consequently, the degree of disability from which they were suffering would be a matter for individual, rather than blanket, determination as the law then provided. For that reason, the Government provided that the pension should not be taken away but rather should be frozen at the 1978 level. A system of reviewing the disabilities of individual veterans was instituted. In some cases the degree of disability pension available was upgraded.

I make that point because it does cause some difficulty in contemplating Senator Macklin's proposed amendment, which seeks retrospective payment of the disability pension available to TB pensioners. Such retrospectivity would extend , of course, to the 1978 period. There could well be veterans who had received some form of increased disability pension during the interim and there would be a problem in reconciling the withdrawal of that benefit with the granting of a further benefit under the retrospective payment of a TB pension that would flow to them. For that reason, severe practical difficulties are involved and the Government will oppose the proposed amendment.

Senator Macklin also drew our attention to the problems involved in the determination process and the fact that a number of cases proceed to the Repatriation Review Tribunal level rather than being determined at lower levels in the system. I wish to point out that approximately 75 per cent of the cases that flow through the determination process in a given year are successfully determined before they reach the Repatriation Review Tribunal. Therefore, only a minority of cases proceed beyond that point. Obviously, they are the ones in which there is a basis for contention, either on legalistic grounds or the common sense grounds to which Senator Macklin has referred.

I would like to re-emphasise some of the points that were made in the second reading speech. The Budget measures are given effect in the Bill and demonstrate in a formal way the Government's continuing concern to ensure that those who have served Australia and our Commonwealth partners and allies in war and warlike conflicts may be certain of receiving adequate compensation for the losses they have suffered, and the sacrifices they have made, during their service. The measures covered in the Bill represent the best Budget, from the point of view of veterans and their dependants, that has been brought down in many years. Honourable senators need not rely on what I say. That has been well and truly stated in public by veterans' organisations. It was particularly gratifying to note the very firm and quick public support given to the Budget decisions by the Returned Services League of Australia.

Two initiatives taken in the Budget are of historic significance. The first relates to the new entitlement to repatriation, medical and hospital treatment for all disabilities suffered by Second World War veterans who receive not less than 50 per cent of the general rate of pension and, of course, any level of service pension. The second is that, from 11 November, no amount of disability pension will be taken into account in assessing the level of service pension received and the eligibility for fringe benefits. It was gratifying to note the very supportive remarks of Senator Macklin and Senator Ryan in respect of that initiative.

The provision means that as from 11 November a single veteran with a temporary and permanently incapacitated pension, for instance, provided he has only a limited amount of other income, will receive the full service pension. He will also be eligible for fringe benefits. That means, in round terms, an increase of more than $50 in the total fortnightly pension of the TPI pensioner. Of course, that figure may be affected by the receipt of other income but, clearly, it is a decision of fundamental importance, a most important indication of the Government's sincerity about its commitment.

I would like to mention also the increase in the amount of income allowed to a person in qualifying for the maximum rate of service pension; the extension of the service pension to merchant mariners of Commonwealth and allied countries and repatriation benefits to all Australian representatives of peacekeeping, monitoring and observing forces. I wish to mention also the extension to double orphans of eligibility for benefits. A whole range of allowances for the more severely disabled veterans has been increased.

The Bill also contains positive measures to aid veterans. In another place an attempt was made to divert attention from those positive measures by using the Bill as a vehicle for speaking about the problems of Vietnam veterans. It is difficult to see what other measures can be adopted immediately in respect of that group of veterans but I would like to deal with a few other matters to indicate exactly what has been done. Nearly three years ago, when the agent orange controversy arose, the Government began its attempts to get at the facts scientifically. It must be realised that we were faced with a situation in which no studies had been directed specifically to that question. A study of the possible effect on servicemen of herbicides used in Vietnam had never been undertaken. Initial studies commissioned by the Government led the researchers to conclude that the focus should be shifted from the narrow area of chemicals towards the possible effects of Vietnam service, as such.

In February of this year I explained publicly the revisions required in the research program. Scientific studies as complex as these inevitably take time. Nothing is achieved by undue haste. Nonetheless, I expect to have the first results of the studies-those concerning birth defects among the children of Vietnam veterans-before the end of this year. I hope by the end of next year to have the results of another study-that concerned with the causes and incidence of death, including suicides, among Vietnam veterans.

In addition, a Senate committee has been examining the evidence on the alleged effects on the health of veterans of chemicals used in Vietnam. Its report is expected soon. It is an all-party committee on which the Government does not have a majority. The committee could not in any way be accused of being biased in favour of the Government. Provision already exists within the repatriation system for compensation to be paid and medical treatment provided to any veteran of the Vietnam conflict who has disabilities related to his service. In the event of a veteran's claim being rejected by a Repatriation Board-which comprises three members, at least one of whom must be nominated by an ex-service organisation-the veteran may appeal to the Repatriation Commission and the Repatriation Review Tribunal, which similarly includes ex-service nominees. In certain cases the matter may be referred to the Federal Court of Australia or to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

Many Vietnam veterans are already receiving compensation for their disabilities . As at 30 June this year some 7,000 of the 46,000 Army, Navy and Air Force personnel who served in Vietnam were receiving disability pensions. To the end of September this year a total of 1,259 Australian veterans had lodged claims for disability in which they mentioned possible contact with chemicals in Vietnam. Of these, 410 have been accepted by the repatriation boards for various reasons not necessarily connected with chemicals while 246 claims were still to be determined.

One of the measures in this Bill will introduce a greater degree of uniformity of liability in the repatriation legislation. This should remove fears expressed by some people that Vietnam veterans might be at a disadvantage compared with some other veterans. Claims that extraordinary numbers of Vietnam veterans have committed suicide since discharge have appeared in some newspapers. These figures have not been substantiated. The Vietnam Veterans Association says it has a register of deaths due to suicide and other causes such as cancer but the details from this register have not been yet revealed to the Government. Conclusive figures cannot be produced from the records of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. At this stage the available figures suggest that there is no reason to believe that the rate of suicide amongst Vietnam veterans is higher than among Australian males of the same age group. I stress that that is not yet a conclusive decision. This question is expected to be settled when the statistics on mortality amongst Vietnam veterans, including suicides, are produced from the study being carried out by the Commonwealth Institute of Health.

The Vietnam Veterans Association is seeking a judicial inquiry into the effects of herbicides on the health of veterans. One of the amendments to be moved by the Opposition to the second reading of this Bill concerns this matter. The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment has been examining since December last year the question of the possible effects of chemicals on the health of Vietnam veterans and their families. It is capable of covering relevant matters. It has similar powers to those of judicial inquiries, including the power to summon witnesses and documents. In some respects, it may have wider powers than a judicial inquiry. The Committee has received submissions from individuals and representatives of various organisations including the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It has questioned individuals and representatives at each session. I understand that the Committee's Chairman expects to present a report on the Vietnam aspect to Parliament during the current sitting.

On 14 January 1981 I announced that hospital treatment was to be provided to Vietnam veterans requiring urgent medical attention. The offer was extended to all Vietnam veterans who presented themselves to the Department for treatment in respect of a condition not accepted as related to their service. They were given access to departmental institutions if medical investigations indicated that the condition required urgent treatment, and it was appropriate to provide the type of care necessary as an in-patient and, of course, that there was spare bed capacity in repatriation hospitals. If beds were not available in repatriation hospitals, accommodation was to be sought in non-repatriation hospitals under normal community arrangements by a new counselling service for Vietnam veterans then being established. These special arrangements were to be reviewed in 12 months time.

On 15 February this year, following a review of the decision to provide Vietnam veterans with urgent treatment in repatriation hospitals, I announced that the Government had decided to retain that benefit and to make two important extensions. The Government decided it would accept the cost of urgent treatment of Vietnam veterans in country hospitals. If the veteran was insured costs would be recouped from the health fund concerned. In addition, the Government decided that, at no cost to the family, wives and children of Vietnam veterans could receive emergency treatment at repatriation general hospitals if the hospitals had facilities to treat them and if such treatment was considered to be necessary by the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service.

The service itself was an important government initiative. I would like to say a little more about its development. After visiting the United States in June and July of last year to see how government agencies were handling veterans' problems and to learn more of United States studies, I announced that I proposed to expand the limited counselling service for Vietnam veterans and to incorporate certain features of the American program. The Government has since established counselling centres in each State capital and in Darwin. The centres are mostly separate from departmental premises and are staffed by personnel who know Vietnam service well. The senior staff are fully qualified counsellors. The centres provide professional counselling, both in terms of psychological and social problems, not only for the veterans themselves but also for their wives and children. They are developing extensive contacts with other groups in the community which provide expertise in particular areas such as marriage guidance and employment.

The latest figures show that fewer than 650 veterans or families have been recorded as having first interviews with the centres since they opened. Although it appears that only a small proportion of the 46,000 who served in Vietnam feel the need for counselling, the Government intends to leave the service intact for some time to ensure that all those who have a genuine need for this type of assistance are able to receive it. We are now considering means of extending the counselling service to provide additional assistance to veterans in non- metropolitan areas. I have been advised by members of a national advisory committee on the establishment of the counselling service. Four of the five members are Vietnam veterans and they include the National Secretary of the Returned Services League and the National President of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia.

That is a brief resume of the programs for Vietnam veterans and their families. It is difficult to see what more can be done at this stage while inquiries are still being concluded. The Government's critics never make it clear what else they might want except perhaps a judicial inquiry which, as I pointed out, will achieve no more than can be achieved by the present Senate inquiry. It has been said in another place that Vietnam veterans do not want automatic compensation for their claimed disabilities. It is interesting to note that, according to a report in the August 1982 issue of Debrief, the official journal of the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, it was decided at a recent meeting attended by Australian and New Zealand Vietnam veterans to mount a campaign 'to challenge government and legislation in order to obtain assistance and help equal to that being provided in Australia'. I must make the point that that decision was made in New Zealand. Obviously, New Zealand veterans and the Australian veterans who met with them believe that the assistance being provided to Australian veterans is impressive and is worth emulating in New Zealand. It is also interesting that the State of Illinois in the United States has established the Agent Orange Study Commission. According to a commissioner of that body, it is widely acknowledged in the United States that Australia is in the forefront in coming to terms with the whole agent orange question.

The cost of war goes on long after the cessation of hostilities. We are still providing pensions and treatment for veterans of the First World War and the survivors of the Second World War and subsequent conflicts in which Australia has been involved. In the case of Vietnam veterans, the traditional approaches of providing compensation by way of service pensions and treatment for disabilities which are related to war service have been maintained. However, the Government has gone beyond the approaches of previous post-war situations in setting up the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service, in providing free treatment in urgent cases and in undertaking specific detailed scientific studies. As further information becomes available and if the need exists we shall seek new ways of helping those who require help.

I refer now to the question of a judicial inquiry. I raise the question of how evidence would be provided to such a judicial inquiry and what means are presently available to Vietnam veterans to receive compensation. I make the point that the repatriation legislation, by virtue of section 47 of the Act, provides that the onus is upon the Government if one likes to disprove the claim of a veteran who seeks support, treatment and other benefits from the Department . That, of course, is a very generous provision. Since the controversy about agent orange arose this section has been drawn to the attention of Vietnam veterans with the intention that they should bring forward their claims to the Department and have them dealt with in the normal way. It has always seemed to us that through that means there is a very generous provision by which people can prove their claims and obtain compensation. There has never been any determined approach by the Government to deny justice, as Senator Ryan suggested in her remarks, to those who are seeking compensation. The machinery is there and does provide an opportunity for Vietnam veterans to test their eligibility to receive compensation for war-caused disabilities. I would like to say that over and over again until we get it across to some people that opportunities for compensation already exit. One therefore has to be concerned about the continued calls for a judicial inquiry on this matter. It is extremely difficult to determine the motives of people who seek that.

There is, of course, the outstanding question of problems caused children by virtue of birth defects arising from exposure to herbicides, other chemicals or whatever during a veteran's service in Vietnam. That is a matter which is, I hope, receiving scientific resolution through studies, the results of which will be coming forward in the next month or two. By that means we will have a basis for establishing scientifically whether there is something that the Government will need to consider further concerning the problem of birth defects. Because of the existence of the Senate Committee and the way in which it has handled its inquiry in taking evidence from all sides-I believe, from what I have read, that it has been very thorough in its examination-the Senate is a vehicle by which the issues surrounding the alleged exposure of soldiers in Vietnam to various chemicals, including agent orange, will be properly heard and determined.

There has been some criticism by persons from the veteran community about the make-up of the Senate Committee, about the people who form part of it and, indeed, about the amount of time which that Committee has given to the issue. In answer to those critics I make the simple point that, as any honourable senator here would know, although a committee sits for a limited number of hours each day and those days might be relatively few compared with the total number of days in a year, that is not the limit of a Senate committee's inquiry. In fact many days are spent in further research. A lot of work is undertaken by staff as well and many days are spent in review and the preparation of reports which are finally brought into this place. For that reason, in trying to remove some of the doubts that surround the Senate Committee's report, I make it quite clear that I believe the Committee's role in relation to this issue has been very substantially underrated by many people in the community. In fact, very unfortunately, in some newspaper articles, it has been denigrated by people who I think do not appreciate the full ramifications of the Senate's powers of inquiry into matters brought before it and in particular to this matter.

This Budget has eliminated gaps and anomalies in services for veterans. It has widened eligibility for treatment and for some benefits. In consultation with the major ex-service organisations we shall continue to extend and improve the veterans' affairs system to deal with changing needs and to provide security and compensation for those who served and made sacrifices for this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What reasons can the Government offer for the complete collapse of Commonwealth funding of pre-schools in Victoria since 1975.
(2) How does the Government justify a drop in Commonwealth contributions to Victorian pre-school capital expenditure from nearly $3m in 1976-77 to just over $5,000 in 1981-82.

(3) Has the introduction of block grants to the States for pre-schools in 1977, in place of the previous 75 per cent Commonwealth funding arrangement, in fact been used to gradually eliminate support for pre-schools altogether; if so, could it be concluded that the Government is not interested in ensuring Victorian parents have the widest possible access to pre-school facilities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Basic responsibility for the provision of pre-school services lies with State Governments. The Commonwealth provides significant General Purpose Revenue to enable the States to set their own priorities and fund services accordingly.
The General Purpose Revenue Grants to the States have increased by 82 per cent since 1978-79.

In addition, the Commonwealth provides the States with funding for pre-schools in the form of an annual block grant through the Children's Services Program. In 1982-83 the grant for Victoria is $9.015m. Between 1975-76 and 1981-82 the amount paid to Victoria through the block grant totalled $78.195m.

(2) Distribution of the pre-school block grant in each State is the prerogative of the State Government which allocates funds for capital expenditure according to its priorities. In Victoria the responsibility for the distribution of the block grant rests with the Health Commission.

(3) The introduction of pre-school block grants to the States in 1977 did not signify the elimination of Commonwealth support for pre-schools. For each financial year since 1977 the total pre-school block grant has exceeded $31m. In 1982-83 the total allocation is $33.09m, of which $9.015m will be provided to Victoria.

In recent years, in recognition that pre-school services are primarily the responsibility of State Governments, the Commonwealth's expenditure in the early childhood field has focused on child care rather than pre-school services. Since 1976 annual expenditure on child care has almost trebled from some $18.1m (27 per cent of the total allocation) in 1976-77 to $47.4m (59 per cent) in 1981-82. Estimated expenditure in 1982-82 is $70.04m, or 68 per cent of the year's allocation.
In Victoria annual Commonwealth expenditure since 1975 on children's services other than pre-school has risen from some $4.1m in 1975-76 to $12.02m in 1981-82 .

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Supporting Parent's Benefit and Widow's Pension

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government sympathetic to the position of those women in the community aged between 40 and 50 who have been taken off supporting parent's benefit or widow's pensions due to their youngest child turning 16 years of age or leaving school.
(2) What assistance does the Government intend to offer those women who are currently prevented from re-applying for benefits until they turn 50.

(3) Is the Government aware that a reduction in the eligibility for the widow's Class B pension from 50 to 40 years of age would offer to many impoverished women the acknowledgement and security of a pension card.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) A female single parent with a qualifying child may be eligible for Class A widow's pension if she is a 'widow'; that is, if her husband (or de facto husband of at least three years standing) has died or she is a divorcee, has been deserted for at least six months, or her husband has been imprisoned for that period. Other single parents may receive the similar supporting parent' s benefit. A Class B widow's pension is available from age 50 for any widow, as defined above, who has no qualifying child, or from age 45 if after her 45th birthday her Class A pension ceases because she no longer has such a child.

The question of whether entitlement for a Class B widow's pension should be widened to provide pensions to younger women without dependants is a complex one . I appreciate that Class A widows who lose their pension before age 45 may see their exclusion as anomalous; on the other hand, many such women may have had work force experience and might be expected to maintain themselves without taxpayer support.

Needy 'widows' who cease to be eligible for a Class A pension before age 45, and supporting parent beneficiaries who cease to have the care of children, may qualify for invalid pension or unemployment, sickness or special benefit. An invalid pensioner is eligible for a pensioner health benefits (PHB) card on the same basis as a widow pensioner or supporting parent beneficiary. As a result of measures announced in the recent Budget, all sickness beneficiaries will be eligible for the same Commonwealth 'pensioner fringe benefits'. Unemployment and special beneficiaries (and low income persons) who are eligible for a Health Care card, are entitled to free medical and hospital treatment and from January 1983 will also receive concessional pharmaceutical benefits.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the ease with which school children in the United States have been able to crack the codes of some of the most sophisticated and confidential computers in that country.
(2) Is it possible for people in Australia to perform the same feats of these American schoolchildren and gain access to information stored in computers used by the Minister's department.
(3) What security precautions have been taken to prevent such invasions of privacy.
(4) Does this ability to penetrate the secrecy of computers pose a grave security risk and leave hundreds of thousands of Australians open to blackmail and blatant invasions of privacy.
(5) Can the Minister give an assurance that confidential information related to his departmental files cannot be obtained by this method of 'plugging in' to computer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) I am conscious of the need for security of computer equipment and programs. The Department follows the comprehensive security guidelines prepared and published by the Office of the Public Service Board. The Department incorporates a number of monitoring processes into its computer systems and maintains a close surveillance of all aspects of existing security measures. While all reasonable precautions to prevent unauthorised access are taken, it is recognised that no overall security system is completely infallible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the basis for the Minister's estimate that it would cost between $8 and $10 from every taxpayer to abolish poverty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no one bench mark for measuring poverty which would command the unqualified assent of everyone. Hence there is no one set of policy measures which would be universally accepted as leading to the abolition of poverty.

I have recently commented, however, about whether the problem of poverty might be tackled by making across-the-board increases in pensions and benefits, as several groups have proposed. Suggestions that have been made include raising all pensions and benefits to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings, the cost of which would be about $3,000m in a full year (or an average of some $9 to $10 a week per taxpayer). The cost of raising all pensions and benefits to 120 per cent of the Henderson poverty line, the poverty benchmark suggested by the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) in its report 'Living on the Edge', would be about $2,800m (or an average of some $8 to $9 a week per taxpayer).

These estimates are, of course, only broad indicators of the cost involved in such proposals. They are not intended to suggest that every taxpayer would have to pay $8 to $10 a week in additional tax to finance them; obviously some taxpayers on lower incomes would pay less than the average while those with higher incomes would pay more.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what circumstances is an annulment of marriage treated in the same way as divorce in respect of the grant of widow's pension.
(2) Under what circumstances are annulment and divorce treated differently, and what is the effect on the pension application of a woman whose marriage has been annulled.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) By paragraph (c) of sub-section 59 (1) of the Social Security Act, the term 'widow' includes 'a woman whose marriage has been dissolved and who has not remarried'. In order to satisfy this definition, dissolution of a valid and subsisting marriage is required. Annulment of a marriage means that the marriage was void from the outset and consequently it does not involve dissolution of a valid and subsisting marriage. Thus, in contrast to the situation of a woman whose marriage has been dissolved, a woman whose marriage has been annulled is not entitled to a widow's pension by reason of the annulment. She may of course qualify for other forms of assistance under the Social Security Act subject to the usual conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the specific guidelines for payment of special benefit.

(2) Are children under 16, who are responsible for themselves or whose parents refuse to accept responsibility for them, entitled to special benefit; if so, how do they apply; and if not, would the Minister acknowledge the growing number of homeless children in this category by providing eligibility for special benefit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Social Security Act provides that special benefit may, at the discretion of the Director-General, be granted to a person who is not in receipt of a pension or to whom unemployment or sickness benefit is not payable and who, by reason of age, physical or mental disability or domestic circumstances or for any other reason, is unable to earn a sufficient livelihood for himself and his dependants.

(2) As a general rule, special benefit is not paid to a child under the age of 16 years. However, all claims for special benefit are examined in the light of the particular circumstances of the claim and benefit may be granted to a child under the age of 16 years where special circumstances exist. For example, special benefit may be paid where the child has been forced to leave home because of such factors as domestic violence against himself and is then unable to support himself. Any child who considers he may be eligible for assistance may claim special benefit through his local social security office.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What reasons can the Government offer for the complete collapse of Commonwealth funding of pre-schools in South Australia since 1975.
(2) What have been the actual payments made for pre-school capital expenditure from 1976-77 to 1981-82, and what are these figures in 1981-82 terms.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Basic responsibility for the provision of pre-school services lies with State governments. The Commonwealth provides significant general purpose revenue to enable the States to set their own priorities and fund services accordingly.
The general purpose revenue grants to the States have increased by 82 per cent since 1978-79.

In addition, the Commonwealth provides the States with funding for pre-schools in the form of an annual block grant through the Children's Services Program. No new capital grants for pre-schools were provided in 1976-77 and 1977-78. Capital expenditure on pre-schools over this period related to the balance of approvals under the 1973-74 interim pre-school program and the 1974-75 pre- school program.
From 1978-79 onwards the pre-school block grant was intended to cover both capital and recurrent expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1982 (Hansard, page 1767) Senator MacGibbon asked a question without notice concerning deficit budgeting by universities.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Universities in the States are established by State law and are self-governing institutions within the confines of their respective Acts. Subject to any constraints imposed upon them by their establishing legislation, universities are able to enter into contracts and incur income debts and obligations. Most universities have some limited income additional to that provided by the Commonwealth and such income is available to them as part of their total budgets.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act contains provisions which recognise that a university may, in some cases, incur over-expenditure in any one year. Provided that such expenditure is certified as being incurred for Commonwealth grant purposes, a university may offset the amount overspent against the following year's Commonwealth grant. Certified over-expenditure of up to one per cent of the annual grant is deemed to be expenditure for the following year. Where there is over-expenditure in excess of one per cent the Minister for Education has a discretion to approve that this be met from funds appropriated for the following year provided he is satisfied that there are special circumstances to justify his approval. Until certified statements of expenditure are presented the Commonwealth is not in a position to examine expenditure by universities. Such statements must be presented not later than 30 September in the year following the year for which the grant is provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1036) Senator Macklin asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to a question I asked on 8 September in relation to the allowance to wives of pensioners who are on a disability allowance and a service pension. The Minister at that time suggested that the wife's allowance had not been increased because other allowance had. Is it not a fact that in 1964 the combined value of the disability special rate , wife's allowance, attendant's allowance and service pension was $10 more than average weekly earnings and that in 1982 it is $1 less? Would not the Minister then agree that, if the wife's allowance had been indexed from $4 to $15, parity with average weekly earnings would have been maintained?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

In 1964, a veteran and his wife, with no other income or assets, who were receiving the special (totally and permantly incapacitated) rate of pension, dependant's pension for wife, attendant's allowance (lower rate) and service pension would have received a total family income of $44.51 a week (85.4 per cent of average weekly earnings). As from 11 November 1982, they will receive $ 304.15 (93.3 per cent of average weekly earnings) provided their other income is less than $50 a week (assets are no longer taken into consideration; only the income from those assets). These amounts compare with average weekly earnings in 1964 of $52.10 a week and for the June quarter of 1982 of $326.00 a week.
The comparison made by Senator Macklin is misleading in the following respects :

(i) his calculation of pension in 1964 incorrectly assumed that a veteran and wife receiving the special (T and PI) rate pension, dependant's pension and attendant's allowance would receive service pension at the maximum rate; and
(ii) the actual disposable income of T and PI pensioners and their wives is considerably in excess of average weekly earnings because the disability pension is not taxable.

With regard to the first point, it should be noted that in 1964 the full amount of disability pension and dependant's pension was taken into account in assessing the rate of service pension payable. This meant that a veteran and wife who were receiving the T and PI rate pension on and dependant's pension would not have received the maximum service pension rate payable at that time of $11.00 a week for the veteran and $6.00 a week for the wife, but would have received $2.73 a week each.

From 11 November 1982, disability and dependant's pensions will be disregarded in assessing the rate of service pension payable and eligibility for fringe benefits. In addition, the income limit at which service pension for married couples is reduced below the maximum rate will increase to $50 a week and the limit at which eligibility for fringe benefits ceases will increase to $90 a week for a married couple. This means that from November 1982, a T and PI pensioner and his wife who also receive attendant's allowance and service pension can have other income up to $50 a week before service pension is reduced and $90 a week other income before fringe benefit eligibility ceases. Most wives of T and PI veterans will now be eligible for free medical treatment under the Pensioner Health Benefits Scheme and this, together with the fact that disability and dependant's pensions and attendant's allowance are tax-free , gives these pensioners a higher disposable income than the average wage earner. Such pensions are in a much superior position to their counterparts in 1964.

Dependants' pensions have not been increased since 1964. Governments have concentrated available funds on ensuring that incapacitated veterans and war widows are adequately compensated through pensions, that they have the best possible medical treatment facilities available to them and that income tested pensions are adequate. The increases in the major repatriation pensions which have occurred as a result of movements in the consumer price index and the increases in other allowances and benefits which have occurred in the Budget context have ensured that the family as a unit receives the benefit of increased pensions and allowances. This is illustrated by the fact that, since 1964, the income through pension available to a T and PI pensioner and his wife receiving attendant's allowance and service pension has increased by approximately 683 per cent despite the fact that depedant's pension has not increased. During this period the CPI has increased by approximately 393 per cent.

The average weekly earnings (before tax) in March 1982 were $316.00. In May 1982 a veteran receiving the T and PI pension, attendant's allowance (lower rate) and service pension and his wife receiving dependant's pension and service pension received $278.76 a week. The equivalent taxable income that a wage earner would need to receive in order to have a take home pay of $278.76 a week would be $356 a week.
